revision.text:
{{Infobox writer | name = Katharine Coman | image = Katharine Coman (Yellow Clover).jpg | imagesize = | birth_date = {{Birth date |1857|11|23}} | birth_place = [[Newark, Ohio]], United States | death_date = {{death date and age|1915|01|11|1857|11|23}} | death_place = [[Wellesley, Massachusetts]], United States | occupation = Professor | nationality = American | partner = [[Katharine Lee Bates]] }} '''Katharine Ellis Coman''' ({{Birth date |1857|11|23}} – {{death date |1915|01|11}}) was an American historian, economist, sociologist, educator, and social activist. Coman worked at [[Wellesley College]] for 35 years as an instructor, professor, and dean. Believing that the discipline of political economy could be harnessed to solve the pressing social problems of the day, Coman created new courses in the discipline. She specialized in research and teaching about the development of the [[American West]], and British and American industrialism. In her work, she criticized [[capitalism]] and was supportive of the [[labor movement]]. She was the only woman co-founder of the American Economics Association, the author of the first important history of industry in the US, and the first female statistics professor in America. Throughout her life, she traveled widely to conduct her economics research. A social activist, Coman supported the [[settlement movement]] and the [[labor movement]]. She shared a home with poet [[Katharine Lee Bates]] for 25 years, and the two women often traveled together. Coman died of breast cancer in 1915. Wellesley College created the Katharine Coman Professorship of Industrial History in her honor. {{TOC limit|2}} == Early life == Coman was born on November 23, 1857, to Martha Ann Seymour Coman (1826–1911) and Levi Parsons Coman (1826–1889) in [[Newark, Ohio|Newark]], [[Ohio]].{{Cite web|url=https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/naming-project/people/coman/|title=Katharine Coman |website=sites.lsa.umich.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-07}}Norley, Katharine. (2006). "Coman, Katharine (1857–1915)," p. 166 in ''The biographical dictionary of American economists, Volume I, A-I,'' edited by Ross B. Emmett''.'' Thoemmes Continuum: London. Upon her birth, Coman's father reportedly said that he would show educators how a girl should be educated.{{Cite web|url=http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/articles/pages/4569/Coman-Katharine-1857-1915.html|title=Coman, Katharine (1857–1915) – Economic History|last=|first=|date=|website=encyclopedia.jrank.org|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 9, 2018}} Her mother had graduated from an Ohio [[female seminary]], and her father had been educated at [[Hamilton College (New York)|Hamilton College]], and thus Coman's received much of her early education at home. She attended the [[University of Michigan]] for two years, left college to teach in [[Ottawa, Illinois]] for two years, and then returned to university. She earned the Bachelor of Philosophy (PhB) degree in 1880, one of only a handful of women to do so.{{cite journal |last1=Vaughn |first1=Gerald F. |title=Katharine Coman: America's First Woman Institutional Economist and a Champion of Education for Citizenship |journal=Journal of Economic Issues |date=2016 |volume=38 |issue=4 |pages=989–1002 |doi=10.1080/00213624.2004.11506753}} She was heavily influenced by the work of [[John Stuart Mill]], which is evident in her later work as economist and historian. Coman attended lectures about socialism while traveling in London.{{Rp|111}} Later in her career, she became influenced by [[Alfred Marshall]] (1890), [[Francis Amasa Walker]] (1883), and [[social Darwinism]]. While at the University of Michigan, Coman studied under Professors [[Charles Kendall Adams]] of the [[German Historical School]]; [[James Burrill Angell]], then president of the university; and [[Henry Carter Adams]], a renowned [[statistician]]. After graduating with her PhB, she joined the faculty at Wellesley College, a newly established private college for women. == Wellesley College == [[File:Wellesley College 1881.JPG|alt=An etching of Wellesley College circa 1881.|thumb|Etching of Wellesley College circa 1881]] Coman was recruited to Wellesley College by [[Alice Freeman Palmer|Alice Freeman]], Wellesley's president, whose goal was to attract idealistic women faculty members to teach young women how to rebuild American society after the economic and social ravages of the [[American Civil War|Civil War]].Ponder, Melinda M. (2017). ''From Sea to Shining Sea: Katharine Lee Bates''. Chicago, IL: Windy City Press. {{ISBN|9781941478486}} Noting her talent for teaching, the president of the University of Michigan, James Burrill Angell, recommended Coman. She first taught English rhetoric, and in 1881 became an instructor in history.Bates, Katharine Lee. (1922). ''Yellow Clover: A Book of Remembrance.'' New York: E. P. Dutton & Company. In 1883, she was promoted to full professor of history. Because Coman believed that economics could address social problems, she urged the Wellesley College administration to offer courses in economics, and in 1883, she taught Wellesley's first [[political economy]] class. To teach students about the practicality of applying economic theory to real world economic and social problems, Coman escorted her students on field trips to Boston's tenement houses, labor union meetings, factories, and sweatshops.{{Cite news|url=https://newarkadvocate.newspapers.com/image/35997882/?terms=Katharine%2BComan|title=Learning to be statesmen|last=|first=|date=5 October 1893|work=The Newark Daily Advocate|access-date=2 September 2018|page=3}} In 1885, at the age of 28, she became professor of history and economics. That same year, she turned down the offer of a position as dean of women at the University of Michigan, stating that she preferred to remain at Wellesley and continue teaching. She was acting dean of Wellesley College from 1899 to 1900; during that period she established a new department of economics and sociology, becoming its head in 1900. She retired from full-time teaching at Wellesley in 1913,{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1913/05/04/100617439.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA®ion=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=93|title=Farewell dinner to Miss Coman|last=|first=|date=4 May 1913|work=The New York Times|access-date=2 September 2018|page=11}} becoming [[professor emeritus]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1913/03/30/archives/new-wellesley-dean-miss-alice-vinton-walte-chosen-by-the-board-of.html|title=New Wellesley dean|last=|first=|date=30 March 1913|work=The New York Times|access-date=2 September 2018|page=8}} About the farewell dinner held in her honor, the ''New York Times'' wrote: "Miss Coman has been so closely associated with the history and development of Wellesley for so long a time that her loss is felt very deeply by the whole college." Coman continued to research and write until her death in 1915. She developed and taught new courses in economics, history, and rhetoric at Wellesley, including Statistical Study of Economic Problems, Industrial History of the United States, and Conservation of Our Natural Resources, all framed by sociological insights related to [[social justice]]. Coman was the first American woman to teach statistics.{{Cite journal|last=Fitzpatrick|first=Paul J.|date=1955|title=The Early Teaching of Statistics in American Colleges and Universities|jstor=2685503|journal=The American Statistician|volume=9|issue=5|pages=12–18|doi=10.2307/2685503}} Wellesley was the only American women's college to offer statistics courses before 1900. According to historian Melinda Ponder, Coman was a popular teacher.{{Rp|66}} Two of her students, Helen Frances Page Bates and Helen Laura Sumner Woodbury, were among the first American women to earn PhDs in economics.{{Rp|994}} Woodbury is recognized as an important historian of labor and a noted economist,{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/Helen-Laura-Sumner-Woodbury|title=Helen Laura Sumner Woodbury {{!}} American economist|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-07-06|language=en}} while Helen Bates became a noted social worker. Coman's papers are held by the Wellesley College Archives.{{cite web|publisher=Wellesley College Archives|url=https://www.wellesley.edu/sites/default/files/assets/departments/libraryandtechnology/files/archives/3p_coman_katharine.pdf|title=Katharine Coman papers|date=August 31, 2017| access-date=July 5, 2018}} In 1921, Wellesley College established the Katharine Coman Professorship of Industrial History to honor her service to the College.{{Rp|1001}} == Notable works == Coman and Elizabeth Kendall coauthored the 1902 book ''A Short History of England for School Use'' based on research that Coman had conducted in England between the years 1886 and 1894. Coman published ''The Industrial History of the United States'' in 1910. Considered the first industrial history of the United States, the book was reprinted nine times before 1915. Her 1911 article, "Some Unsettled Problems of Irrigation," was the first article published in the newly formed journal''[[American Economic Review]].''{{Rp|36}} Her 1912 work ''Economic Beginnings of the Far West: How We Won the Land Beyond the Mississippi''{{Rp|xi}} was considered by contemporaneous scholars to be Coman's ''[[magnum opus]],''{{Rp|166}}{{efn|According to [[Katharine Lee Bates]], the book "best expresses [Coman's] vigorous and adventurous personality.{{Rp|xi}}}} and "one of the most important fruits of the [[Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching]]."{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1912/11/17/issue.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA®ion=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article|title=Two notable books published recently by members of faculty|last=|first=|date=17 November 1912|work=The New York Times|access-date=2 September 2018|page=15}} The book outlined the economic history of the [[American West]].{{efn|It included chapters on the [[Spanish exploration of the Pacific Northwest|early Spanish explorers]], [[Spanish missions in California]], [[Santa Fe de Nuevo Mexico|Santa Fe trade]], the [[Russian exploration of the Pacific Northwest]], the beaver fur trade, the [[Mexican–American War]] and subsequent [[Mexican Cession|cession]] of what became the [[American Southwest]], the [[Mormon pioneers|Mormon migration]] to [[Utah]], early explorers of the West, and the creation of the states of [[Kansas]] and [[Oregon]].}} In this work, Coman describes the historical economic processes that led to the Far West coming under the control of [[settlers]]. She found that settlers were more economically successful than [[Exploration of North America|explorers]], [[North American fur trade|traders]], trappers, and [[North American Indians|indigenous peoples]] because the settlers built permanent settlements, reproduced at a higher rate, and established [[social networks|networks of collaboration]].{{Rp|354}} Settlement movement activist [[Jane Addams]], a close friend, urged Coman to research social insurance programs in Europe in order to establish similar programs in the United States. Coman studied social insurance in England, Spain, Denmark, and Sweden, but poor health prevented her from continuing her research. Her manuscript, "Unemployment Insurance: A Summary of European Systems" was published after her death in 1915.{{efn|Coman's notes from the study of old age pensions and unemployment social insurance in Europe are housed at Wellesley in the Katharine Coman Papers Collection.}} == Social activism == Coman was passionate about social and economic issues, especially women's education, poverty, immigration, and labor. Throughout her life, she was active in social reform movements, especially the labor movement and the settlement movement. She served as the president of the electoral board and chair of the standing committee of the [[National College Settlements Association]] in 1900. Coman organized a group of immigrant women who worked in Boston sweatshops,{{Rp|166}} naming the group an "Evening Club for Tailoresses," and attempted to found a tailor shop that could have been an alternative to sweatshops. She assisted in organizing the [[1910 Chicago garment workers' strike]],{{Cite web|url=http://womhist.alexanderstreet.com/immstrike/doclist.htm|title=The 1910 Chicago Garment Workers' Strike, Document List|website=womhist.alexanderstreet.com|access-date=2018-07-06}} which involved 40,000 factory workers.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1988-06-12/features/8801070825_1_strike-spread-shops-immigrant-workers|title=The Strike That Shook Up An Entire Industry|last=Sawyers|first=June|date=June 12, 1988|work=Chicago Tribune|access-date=September 9, 2018}} Coman also worked with the [[Women's Trade Union League]].{{Rp|166}} Working with her economist and sociologist friend [[Emily Greene Balch]] and other women, Coman co-founded Denison House,{{Rp|166}} a college women's [[settlement house]] located in Boston in 1892, serving as its first chair. Denison House provided a center for Boston's labor activists, and is thought to be the first settlement house on the East Coast. == Personal life == [[File:Katherine Lee Bates.jpg|alt=a middle aged woman wearing glasses|thumb|[[Katharine Lee Bates]], author of the words to "[[America the Beautiful]]"]] For 25 years, Coman lived in a "[[Boston marriage]]"Faderman, Lillian. (1999). ''To Believe in Women: What Lesbians Have Done for America--A History.'' Boston, MA: Houghton Mifflin Company. {{ISBN|039585010}}{{Rp|192}} with Wellesley professor and poet [[Katharine Lee Bates]],D'Emilio, John, and Estelle Freedman. (2012). ''Intimate Matters: A History of Sexuality in America'' (Third Edition)''.'' Chicago, IL: University of Chicago Press. {{ISBN|9780226923802}}{{Rp|190}} the author of "[[America the Beautiful]]". Such partnerships were so common among Wellesley faculty that they were called "Wellesley marriages".{{Rp|185; 191–2}} Coman and Bates shared a house they named "the Scarab" with Bates' mother, Cornelia, and her sister, Jeannie.{{Rp|153}} The women reportedly enjoyed life together as family.Burgess, Dorothy. (1952). ''Dream and Deed: The Story of Katharine Lee Bates.'' Norman, OK: University of Oklahoma Press.{{Rp|176}} Coman frequently traveled for her research on economic history; she visited Europe, the American West, Scandinavia, and Egypt. Bates accompanied her on many of these trips. Some scholars believe the two women were a lesbian couple.{{Rp|196}}{{efn|Writing in 1952, Burgess wrote that Coman was Bates' "dearest companion of her life."{{Rp|209}}}} == Breast cancer and death == Coman first discovered a lump in her left breast in the fall of 1911 and underwent two surgeries in the following months. At the time, medical doctors did not understand the nature of breast cancer, its causes or its treatments, so the prognosis for Coman was poor.{{cite journal|last=Leopold|first=Ellen|date=|year=2006|title=My soul is among lions: Katharine Lee Bates' account of the illness and death of Katharine Coman|url=|journal=[[Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies]]|volume=23|issue=1|pages=60–73|doi=10.1353/leg.2006.0008|ref=harv|via=}} Coman died at home in January 1915 at the age of 58.{{Rp|62}} She died in a room the family had named Bohemia, as it looked out over the trees and gardens below.{{Rp|176}} At the time of her death, Coman was working on an industrial history of New England.{{Rp|1001}}{{Cite news|url=https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/01/12/105034927.html?action=click&contentCollection=Archives&module=ArticleEndCTA®ion=ArchiveBody&pgtype=article&pageNumber=9|title=Woman historian dead|last=|first=|date=12 January 1915|work=The New York Times|access-date=2 September 2018|page=9}} During Coman's illness, Coman and Bates' women friends—many of them also in Wellesley marriages—took Coman out for walks and visits, and invited her to stay at their country homes. They prepared meals for Coman and Bates, brought flowers and fresh vegetables, and performed tasks and services to keep Coman's spirits up. Bates chronicled Coman's illness in her diary, noting hospital visits, surgical procedures, and details about Coman's pain and suffering. According to cancer historian Ellen Leopold, in the days after Coman's death, Bates wrote a memorial to Coman that was designed to be circulated privately among the women's close friends and family.{{Rp|61}}{{cite journal |last1=Bates |first1=Katharine Lee |title=For Katharine Coman's Family and Innermost Circle of Friends. Not for Print nor in any way for General Circulation. |journal=Legacy |date=2006 |volume=23 |issue=1 |pages=74–85 |doi=10.1353/leg.2006.0002}} Leopold believes that the book, "For Katharine Coman's Family and Innermost Circle of Friends," is the first breast cancer narrative in American literature.{{Rp|61}} Near the end of Coman's life, the two women exchanged loving farewells through reciting poems and psalms to each other.{{Rp|176}} Several years after Coman's death, Bates continued to mourn and to recall Coman's suffering. In 1922, she published a book of poems about Coman's illness in the book ''Yellow Clover: A Book of Remembrance''.{{cite journal |last1=Schwarz |first1=Judith |title="Yellow Clover": Katharine Lee Bates and Katharine Coman |journal=Frontiers: A Journal of Women Studies |date=1979 |volume=4 |issue=1 |pages=59–67 |doi=10.2307/3346671 |jstor=3346671 }}{{efn|In the poem, "In Cedar Hill Cemetery (Newark, Ohio)," Bates writes:
O ashes, memory of moral love, Sealed in your urn beneath the greensward, pure From evil, what am I to weep above Your beautiful and tranquil sepulture?{{Rp|41}}
}} The book's title emerged from the fact that the "two Katharines," as the women were known, would send each other sprigs of yellow clover as tokens of affection.{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/250340881|title=Life of song's author reveals a profile in literary courage|last=Watson|first=Catherine|date=15 December 2002|work=Star Tribune|access-date=2 September 2018|page=G7-8}} == Assessment == {{multiple images|direction=vertical|width=225| |image1=Economic beginnings of the Far West- how we won the land beyond the Mississippi (1912) (14778772865).jpg|alt1=illustration from Coman's book |image2=Economic beginnings of the Far West- how we won the land beyond the Mississippi (1912) (14776383884).jpg|alt2=a map showing the [[American West]]|caption2=Illustrations from Coman's 1912 book, ''Economic Beginnings of the Far West: How We Won the Land Beyond the Mississippi.'' }} A review of Coman's book ''Economic Beginnings of the Far West: How We Won the Land Beyond the Mississippi'' (1912) in the ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' stated that "the author is one of those new women who have shown what may be accomplished in the way of research by method and industry and a great deal of enthusiasm."{{Cite news|url=https://www.newspapers.com/image/27421244|title=Beginnings of Far West: An Elaborate Work in Two Volumes by Katharine Coman|last=|first=|date=10 November 1912|work=San Francisco Chronicle|access-date=2 September 2018|page=48}} In a 1913 review of her book, economist [[Thomas Nixon Carver]] praises Coman's narrative style and lively prose.{{cite journal |last1=Carver |first1=T. N. |title=Review of ''Economic Beginnings of the Far West. How We Won the Land Beyond the Mississippi'' |journal=The American Economic Review |date=1913 |volume=3 |issue=2 |pages=353–355 |jstor=1827962 }} Also writing in 1913, economist Frederic Paxson criticized the book arguing that there were factual errors and inaccurate citations, and that the data for the book were already widely available in university research libraries. Paxson does credit Coman with having prepared an extensive bibliography and for providing extensive notes for the book.Paxson, Frederic L. (1913). Economic Beginnings of the Far West: How We Won the Land beyond the Mississippi [by] Katharine Coman. ''The American Historical Review''. 4, 821. {{ISSN|0002-8762}}. This two-volume book, is today hailed as a classic and was reprinted twice; Macmillan in 1925, and Kelly in 1969. In 2011, the ''[[The American Economic Review|American Economic Review]]'' commemorated its first hundred years by publishing a list of the top twenty articles in the journal's history. Coman's 1911 article "Some Unsettled Problems of Irrigation," published in 1911, was the first article published by the journal{{cite journal |last1=Libecap |first1=Gary D |title=Institutional Path Dependence in Climate Adaptation: Coman's "Some Unsettled Problems of Irrigation" |journal=American Economic Review |date=2011 |volume=101 |issue=1 |pages=64–80 |doi=10.1257/aer.101.1.64}} and was reprinted in the 2011 issue. The article analyzed [[Water resources law|water rights]], access, and availability.{{cite journal |last1=Arrow |first1=Kenneth J |last2=Bernheim |first2=B. Douglas |last3=Feldstein |first3=Martin S |last4=McFadden |first4=Daniel L |last5=Poterba |first5=James M |last6=Solow |first6=Robert M |title=100 Years of the 100 years of the ''American Economic Review'': The Top 20 Articles |journal=American Economic Review |date=2011 |volume=101 |issue=1 |pages=1–8 |doi=10.1257/aer.101.1.1}} Also in this issue of the ''American Economic Review,'' economist Gary D. Libecap noted that Coman's work continues to be relevant today, particularly for scholars interested in the economics of [[climate change]]. [[Elinor Ostrom]], an American political economist, believes that Coman's article continues to provide "insight into the problems of collective action related to irrigation in the American West."{{cite journal |last1=Ostrom |first1=Elinor |title=Reflections on "Some Unsettled Problems of Irrigation" |journal=American Economic Review |date=2011 |volume=101 |issue=1 |pages=49–63 |doi=10.1257/aer.101.1.49}}{{Rp|49}} Gerald F. Vaughn, a contemporary economist writing in 2004, proposes that Coman was America's first female [[Institutional economics|institutional economist]]. Vaughn notes other important facts about Coman that frame her as a pioneer for women academics, including the fact that at the time, the discipline and profession of economics was dominated by men.{{Rp|989}} She was the only woman among the group of economists who founded the [[American Economic Association]] in 1885 and she was the first American woman to become a statistics professor. Vaughn notes that her contributions to economics and social history went beyond being the "first woman," and included being the author of the first article to be published in the ''[[The American Economic Review|American Economic Review]]'' in 1911, and the writer of the first industrial history of the US.{{Rp|989}} The University of Michigan "Naming Project" notes that she was one of the first historians to use local newspaper articles and government documents as [[primary source]]s in her teaching and writing. Vaughn highlights the fact that she traveled and interviewed widely to gather the data for her work.{{citation needed|date=September 2018}} According to Vaughn, Coman's extensive work on the processes of institutional change in the American West made her an influential industrial historian. Her text, ''The Industrial History of the United States'' (1905; revised 1910; republished by Arno Press 1973) was widely used as a textbook for decades. == Selected publications == === Books === * ''The Growth of the English Nation'' (1894) * ''History of England'' (1899) * ''A Short history of England'' with Elizabeth Kendall * ''English History Told by English Poets'' (1902) ({{ISBN|0-8369-6097-1}}) with [[Katharine Lee Bates]] * ''Industrial History of the United States'' (1905; revised 1910; reprinted 1973) * ''Economic Beginnings of the Far West: How We Won the Land Beyond the Mississippi'' (1912; 1925; 1969) === Articles === * {{cite journal |last1=Coman |first1=Katharine |title=The Tailoring Trade and the Sweating System |journal=Publications of the American Economic Association |date=1891 |volume=6 |issue=1/2 |pages=144–147 |jstor=2560467 }} * {{cite journal |last1=Coman |first1=Katharine |title=Wages and Prices in England, 1261–1701 |journal=Journal of Political Economy |date=1893 |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=92–94 |jstor=1819834 }} * {{cite journal |last1=Coman |first1=Katharine |title=The History of Contract Labor in the Hawaiian Islands |journal=Publications of the American Economic Association |date=1903 |volume=4 |issue=3 |pages=1–61 |jstor=2485748 }} * {{cite journal |last1=Coman |first1=Katharine |title=The Negro as a Peasant Farmer |journal=Publications of the American Statistical Association |date=1904 |volume=9 |issue=66 |pages=39–54 |doi=10.2307/2276298|jstor=2276298 }} * {{cite journal |last1=Coman |first1=Katharine |last2=Bogart |first2=Ernest L. |last3=Ely |first3=Richard T. |last4=Gay |first4=Edwin F. |title=Stages of Economic Development.-Discussion |journal=Publications of the American Economic Association |date=1907 |volume=8 |issue=1 |pages=127–136 |jstor=2999900 }} * Coman, Katharine. (1911). "Some Unsettled Problems of Irrigation." ''American Economic Review'' 1(1): 1–19. Reprinted in 2011 as ''American Economic Review'' 101: 36–48. == References == ;Notes {{notelist}} ;Citations {{reflist}} == External links == * {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021217163922/http://www.startribune.com/stories/1694/3524889.html |date=17 December 2002 |title=A private life (note photo) }} * {{Internet Archive author|sname=Katharine Ellis Coman}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Coman, Katharine}} [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1915 deaths]] [[Category:American educators]] [[Category:American economists]] [[Category:Women economists]] [[Category:People from Newark, Ohio]] [[Category:University of Michigan alumni]] [[Category:Deaths from cancer in Massachusetts]] [[Category:Wellesley College faculty]] [[Category:Women statisticians]] [[Category:Statistics educators]] [[Category:Deaths from breast cancer]] [[Category:Activists from Ohio]]

revision.text:
'''Katherine Schipper''' is an American [[accounting research|accounting researcher]] and educator.
Currently the Thomas F. Keller professor of accounting at [[Duke University]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fuqua.duke.edu/faculty/alpha/schipper.htm |title=Faculty at Duke University's Fuqua School of Business: Katherine Schipper}}</ref> she has also been a professor at [[University of Chicago]] and [[Carnegie-Mellon University]]. She is a past president of the [[American Accounting Association]]. Also, she has taught the MBA programs at [[Goethe University Frankfurt|University of Frankfurt]]'s [[Goethe Business School]].
For many years, she was editor of the ''[[Journal of Accounting Research]]'', which is hosted at the University of Chicago.
She received the Outstanding Accounting Educator Award of the American Accounting Association in 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aaahq.org/newsarc/schipper.htm |title=Katherine Schipper: Outstanding Accounting Educator Award Winner |publisher=[[American Accounting Association]]}}</ref> She began a five-year term as a member of the [[Financial Accounting Standards Board]] in 2001,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fasb.org/news/nr_schipper.shtml|title=Katherine Schipper Named to FASB |date=2001-01-24 |publisher=Financial Accounting Standards Board}}</ref> and completed that in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fasb.org/news/nr012006.shtml|date=2006-01-20 |title=News Release: FASB Member Katherine Schipper Will Not Seek Reappointment |publisher=Financial Accounting Standards Board}}</ref> In 2007, Schipper was inducted into the [[Accounting Hall of Fame]].<ref name=memberlist>{{cite web|url=http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/ |title=Membership in The Accounting Hall of Fame |publisher=Ohio State University}}</ref> She was the first woman and the 81st inductee.
== Education == She has a B.A. summa cum laude from the University of Dayton and M.B.A., M.A. and Ph.D. from the University of Chicago.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Katherine Schipper Ph.D.: Executive Profile & Biography - Businessweek|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/Research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=8015393&privcapId=345329&previousCapId=4205486&previousTitle=Main%2520Line%2520Health,%2520Inc.|website = Businessweek.com|accessdate = 2015-08-11}}</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://fisher.osu.edu/departments/accounting-and-mis/the-accounting-hall-of-fame/membership-in-hall/katherine-schipper/ Biography upon induction into Accounting Hall of Fame]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Schipper, Katherine}} [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Accounting academics]] [[Category:Duke University faculty]] [[Category:University of Chicago faculty]] [[Category:Carnegie Mellon University faculty]] [[Category:Financial Accounting Standards Board members]]
{{US-academic-bio-stub}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1)
/* Life and career */
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox writer |image = | | name = Lan Samantha Chang | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1965}} | birth_place = [[Appleton, Wisconsin]]Birnbaum, Robert, [http://www.themorningnews.org/archives/personalities/birnbaum_v_lan_samantha_chang.php "Lan Samantha Chang"], [[The Morning News (online magazine)|The Morning News]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = | nationality = US | period = | genre = Novel, short story | subject = | movement = | notableworks = ''Hunger''
''Inheritance'' | spouse = | partner = | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | signature = | alma_mater = [[Yale University]], [[Harvard University]], [[University of Iowa]] | website = }} '''Lan Samantha Chang''' (張嵐; [[pinyin]]: Zhāng Lán), born 1965, is an American [[novelist|writer of novels]] and [[short story|short stories]]. She is Professor of English at the [[University of Iowa]] and Director of the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]]. == Life and career == Samantha Chang was born in [[Appleton, Wisconsin]], the daughter of [[Han Chinese|Chinese]] parents who survived the [[World War II]] [[Japanese occupation of China]] and later emigrated to the United States. Chang has received fellowships from [[Stanford University]] (the [[Stegner Fellowship]]) and [[Princeton University]]. She served as the Briggs-Copeland Lecturer of Creative Writing at [[Harvard University]]. Chang received an [[Master of Fine Arts|M.F.A.]] in Creative Writing from the [[University of Iowa]], an [[Master of Public Administration|M.P.A.]] from Harvard University, and a BA in East Asian Studies from [[Yale University]].[http://us.penguingroup.com/static/rguides/us/hunger.html Interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070328195543/http://us.penguingroup.com/static/rguides/us/hunger.html |date=March 28, 2007 }} – Penguin Publishing website At Yale, she served as managing editor of the [[Yale Daily News]], and at Harvard, she received a fellowship from the [[Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study]]. Chang is a Professor of English at the University of Iowa and the Director of the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]] — the first female, and the first Asian American, to hold that position. She also teaches in the [[Warren Wilson College MFA Program for Writers]]. In 2008 she received a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] and in the fall of 2015 she accepted a fellowship at the [[American Library in Paris]]. The five stories in ''Hunger'' (1998) deal mainly with the position of [[Chinese American|Chinese in America]], though the last of them is set in pre-Communist Shanghai. ''Inheritance'' (2004) is the story of a wealthy but declining family in [[Republican China]], beginning in 1925 and extending through the period of the Japanese invasion and the post-war flight to [[Taiwan]] and then the United States. Chang received the 2005 [[PEN/Beyond Margins Award]] for ''Inheritance''. Her essay "The Perfect Gift" appears in the anthology ''Knitting Yarns: Writers on Knitting'', published by [[W. W. Norton & Company]] in November 2013. == Bibliography == * ''Hunger: A Novella and Stories'' (1998) * ''Inheritance: A Novel'' (2004) * ''All Is Forgotten, Nothing Is Lost: A Novel'' (2010) == See also == {{Portal|Literature}} *[[List of Asian American writers]] == Critical studies == *Jonathan Freedman. "Transgressions of a Model Minority." ''[[Shofar: An Interdisciplinary Journal of Jewish Studies]]'', 2005 Summer; 23 (4): 69–97. *Hetty Lanier Keaton. ''Feeding Hungry Ghosts: Food, Family, and Desire in Stories by Contemporary Chinese American Women.'' Dissertation Abstracts International, Section A: The Humanities and Social Sciences, 2002 July; 63 (1): 187–88. U of Tulsa, 2002. == References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20030828183445/http://www.bedfordstmartins.com/LITLINKS/fiction/chang.htm Short biography and interview] (archived 2003) {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chang, Lan Samantha}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American writers of Chinese descent]] [[Category:John F. Kennedy School of Government alumni]] [[Category:Stanford University alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:University of Iowa alumni]] [[Category:University of Iowa faculty]] [[Category:Writers from Appleton, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:Rona Jaffe Foundation Writers' Award winners]]

revision.text:
'''Leroy Seat''' (born August 15, 1938) is a former chancellor (1996–2004) of Seinan Gakuin <ref>[http://www.seinan-gu.ac.jp/eng/ Seinan Gakuin University<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and full-time faculty member of [[Seinan Gakuin University]] (1968–2004) in [[Fukuoka prefecture|Fukuoka]], [[Japan]]. He was a [[Baptist]] missionary to Japan from 1966 to 2004 and now lives in his home state of [[Missouri]], where he conducts his public activities under the auspices of 4-L Ministries.<ref>[http://www.4-l.org/ 4-L Ministries-* Life * Love * Light * Liberty *<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Seat is president of the Seinan Gakuin 4-L Foundation, Inc., a non-profit organization seeking to help Seinan Gakuin fulfill its mission through supporting and enhancing the presence and witness of Christian teachers and other Christian workers at Seinan Gakuin.
4-L Publications has recently published Seat's book ''Fed Up with Fundamentalism: A Historical, Theological, and Personal Appraisal of Christian Fundamentalism''.<ref>[http://www.4-l.org/4.html 4-L Ministries-* Life * Love * Light * Liberty *<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

This is a list of teachers who have married their students. The list should include only persons who are notable, as defined as being someone who already has an article about them on Wikipedia. {{Expand list|date=April 2015}}
==A== * [[Peter Abélard]] married [[Héloïse d'Argenteuil]]
==B== * Jacqueline May "Jackie" Battley married [[Newt Gingrich]]
==D== * [[Charles Melville Dewey]] married [[Julia Henshaw Dewey|Julia Henshaw]]<ref name="Dearinger(U.S.)2004">{{cite book|author1=David Bernard Dearinger|author2=National Academy of Design (U.S.)|title=Paintings and Sculpture in the Collection of the National Academy of Design: 1826-1925|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PHH45aYubp4C&pg=PR20|year=2004|publisher=Hudson Hills|isbn=978-1-55595-029-3}}</ref>
==F== * [[James Earle Fraser (sculptor)|James Earle Fraser]] married [[Laura Gardin Fraser]] (1913)
==H== * [[Robert Henri]] was twice married to students of his, Linda Craige (1898) and [[Marjorie Organ]] (1908)
==K== *[[Aliza Kezeradze]] married [[Ivo Pogorelić]] in 1980.
==L== * [[Mary Kay Letourneau]] married Vili Fualaau in 2005.
==M== [[Arthur Frank Mathews]] married Lucia Kleinhans.<ref>Opitz, Glenn B, Editor, Mantle Fielding's Dictionary of American Painters, Sculptors & Engravers, Apollo Book, Poughkeepsie NY, 1986 p. 592</ref>
==T== * [[Brigitte Macron|Brigitte Trogneux]] married her former high school student [[Emmanuel Macron]] in 2007, who is currently serving as [[President of France]].
==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Teachers who married their students}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Louise Southgate | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1857|02|20 |mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Walton, Kentucky]] | death_date = {{death date and age |1941|08|14 |1857|02|20 |mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Walton, Kentucky]] | occupation = physician, birth control advocate and educator, child welfare advocate and suffragist }} '''Louise Southgate''' (February 20, 1857 – August 14, 1941)<ref name="Kenton">{{cite web|title=Southgate, Louise (Dr.) |url=http://www.kentonlibrary.org/2013/southgate-louise-dr|website=Kenton County Public Library|accessdate=11 December 2016}}</ref> was one of the first women physicians in Northern Kentucky where she advocated for girls in the juvenile court system and was an early proponent of [[birth control]]. Besides her medical practice and outreach, she led many efforts for the American [[women's suffrage]] movement through her local clubs and the [[Kentucky Equal Rights Association]].
==Early life== The eldest of the eight living children of Bernard and Eleanor Flemming Southgate,<ref>{{cite web| title= Eleanor Flemming (1833-1871) |url=https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Flemming-196 | website=WikiTree | accessdate=11 December 2016 }}</ref> Louise Southgate was born February 20, 1857, in [[Walton, Kentucky]]. She was educated at Western College in [[Oxford, Ohio]], then graduated with a medical degree from Laura Memorial College in [[Cincinnati, Ohio]].<ref name="Who">{{cite book|editor1-last=Leonard|editor1-first=John William|title=Woman's Who's Who of America: A Biographical Dictionary of Contemporary Women of the United States and Canada, Volume 1|date=1914|publisher=The American Commonwealth Co.|location=New York|page=767|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=COsLAAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA767&dq=Louise%20Southgate&pg=PA767#v=snippet&q=southgate&f=false|accessdate=11 December 2016|chapter=Southgate, Louise}}</ref> She then spent two years studying in hospitals in New York and Europe, traveling as far as to the [[Pasteur Institute]] in France for advanced work.<ref name="Suite">{{cite journal | author= Linda Vaccariello | title=Suite Dreams | journal=Cincinnati Magazine | date = April 1993 | issue = 26 | page = 58 | url= https://books.google.com/?id=fx4DAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA58&lpg=PA58&dq=louise+southgate+kentucky#v=onepage&q=louise%20southgate%20kentucky&f=false | accessdate= 11 December 2016}}</ref> She lived with her younger sister Virginia and never married.
==Professional career== Dr. Southgate started practicing medicine at the Presbyterian Hospital in Cincinnati in 1893 and also taught at the Laura Memorial College in 1894. She then left for Europe where she practiced medicine for two years. Returning to the U.S. she took up as a clinician again at the Presbyterian Hospital and to the Laura Memorial College where she taught surgical pathology in 1897.<ref name="Who" /> She became a member of the [[American Medical Association]], Cincinnati chapter. In 1910 she purchased her maternal grandmother's ancestral home, (the old Thomas Kennedy Home at 124 Garrard Street) and used it also for her private practice.<ref name="Kenton" /> Later, she also worked at the Booth Memorial Hospital as well as its auxiliary.<ref name="Encyc">{{cite encyclopedia | entry= Southgate, Louise | title = The Encyclopedia of Northern Kentucky | editor1 = Paul A. Tenkotte | editor2 = James C. Claypool | publisher = University Press of Kentucky | place = Lexington, Kentucky | date = 2015 | page = 843}}</ref> She wrote scholarly articles, including for the State Medical Journal of Kentucky.<ref name="Who" />
===Community medicine outreach=== Dr. Southgate was part of the growing movement in women's reproductive health and family planning of the time. She spoke on hygiene ("Care of the Growing Girl"), birth control and eugenics ("Sociological Status of Women"), connecting this with women's rights (e.g., "Women's Duties in Civil Affairs") for women's clubs, Mothers' meetings, as well as for the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union]].<ref name="Who" /> Her work with schools and local clinics helped start the requirements for physical examinations for schoolchildren in Covington.<ref name="Encyc" />
In 1905, Dr. Southgate spent some time at the [[Hindman Settlement School]] in Knott County, eastern Kentucky, where she taught classes and practiced medicine.<ref name="Kenton" /> She was advocating for women's health concerns there long before the more famous [[Mary Carson Breckinridge]] of the [[Frontier Nursing Service]] or Jean Tachau<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=CcceBgAAQBAJ&lpg=PA866&dq=appalachia%20kentucky%20birth%20control&pg=PA866#v=onepage&q=tachau&f=false</ref> worked in this area.
===Women's clubs and suffrage organizations=== Her work with women's clubs and suffrage organizations was extensive. A partial list of her memberships follows: * Emergency Association of Covington, president<ref>{{cite book | title = Official Register and Directory of Women's Clubs in America | first = Helen M. | last = Winslow| publisher = J.B. Pond Lyceum Bureau | place = New York | volume = XXI | date = 1919 | page = 129 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=pX0fAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=louise+southgate+kentucky#v=onepage&q=louise%20southgate&f=false |accessdate = 11 December 2016}}</ref> * General Federation of Women's Clubs * Kentucky Equal Rights Association, served as KERA press superintendent <ref>{{cite book | first = Lynn E. | last = niedermeier | title = Eliza Calvert Hall: Kentucky Author and Suffragist | publisher = University Press of Kentucky | place = Lexington | date = 2015 | page = 148}}</ref> and State Historian * Kentucky State Federation of Women's Clubs * National Equal Rights Association * Ohio State Federation of Women's Clubs * Woman's Club of Cincinnati
In 1910 she spoke at the 21st [[Kentucky Equal Rights Association]] (KERA) state convention in Covington on the "Sisterhood of Women." She offered a resolution at that meeting that the KERA "extend cordial greetings to the Ky. State Federations of Colored Women's Clubs."<ref>{{cite web | title = Reports of the Twenty-First and Twenty-Second Annual Meetings of the Kentucky Equal Rights Association Held at Covington, November 14-15-16, 1910 and Louisville, October 25, 1911. | place = Newport | publisher = The Newport Printing Co. | pages = 6–7 | url = https://archive.org/stream/minutesofannualc7913kent#page/6/mode/2up }}</ref> Dr. Southgate's influence was revealed in that it was also resolved at that convention that KERA formally requested that the State Board of Charitable Institutions appoint a woman physician at the state asylum for the Insane at Hopkinsville and that each local chapter would begin lobbying for establishing a juvenile court if there wasn't one already in that county.
In 1912 she spoke for suffrage in Cincinnati during the campaign for a suffrage amendment of the Ohio Constitution.<ref name="Who" />
==Hobbies== Dr. Southgate was an avid Egyptologist and collected many artifacts that decorated her historic home in Covington (now known as the Kennedy-Southgate House).<ref name="Suite" />
==Death== After her sister Virginia died in September 1929,<ref>{{cite web | title = Virginia Southgate | website = WikiTree | url = https://www.wikitree.com/wiki/Southgate-80 | accessdate = 11 December 2016}}</ref> Dr. Southgate retired from medical practice. After a long illness and at 84 years old, she died on August 14, 1941, at the home of her sister Eleanor Green in Walton, Kentucky.<ref name="Encyc" /> She was buried in Linden Grove Cemetery in Covington.<ref>https://networks.h-net.org/dr-louise-southgate</ref> The St. Luke Hospitals named their Women's Center after her in 1990; and her legacy was honored by an entry in the [[Kentucky Women Remembered]] collection by the Kentucky Commission on Women in 2000.
==Works== * {{cite journal|last1=Southgate, M.D.|first1=Louise|title=Prevalence and Mortality of Epidemic Pneumonia|journal=Virginia Medical Semi-monthly|date=1905|volume=IX|pages=107–108|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ffw1AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA107#v=snippet&q=louise%20southgate&f=false|accessdate=11 December 2016}}
==See also== *[[Kentucky Equal Rights Association]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography==
* {{Cite encyclopedia |last= Daniels |first= Betty Maddox |editor-last= Tenkotte |editor-first= Paul A. |encyclopedia= The Encyclopedia of Northern Kentucky |title= Louise Southgate |date= 2014 |publisher= University Press of Kentucky|location= Lexington |pages= 842–43}} * {{cite journal|last1=Mueller|first1=Jan|title=Dr. Louise Southgate|journal=The Journal of Kentucky Studies |date=September 2004|volume=21|pages=144–54}} * {{cite book|last1=Poweleit|first1=Alvin C.|title=Bicentennial of Physicians in Northern Kentucky Past and Present|date=1977|publisher=Vesper Printing|location=Newport, Kentucky|page=78}} * {{cite book|editor1-last=Leonard|editor1-first=John William|title=Woman's Who's Who of America: A Biographical Dictionary of Contemporary Women of the United States and Canada, Volume 1|date=1914|publisher=The American Commonwealth Co.|location=New York|page=767|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=COsLAAAAIAAJ&lpg=PA767&dq=Louise%20Southgate&pg=PA767#v=snippet&q=southgate&f=false|accessdate=11 December 2016|chapter=Southgate, Louise}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Southgate, Louise}} [[Category:American suffragists]] [[Category:1857 births]] [[Category:1941 deaths]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:Sex educators]] [[Category:American women's rights activists]] [[Category:Women in Kentucky politics]] [[Category:People from Kentucky]] [[Category:Kentucky women in health]] [[Category:American women physicians]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.2)
revision.text:
'''Marianella P. Machado''' (born August 4, 1959) is a Venezuelan writer and composer.
==Biography== Marianella Machado was born in [[Caracas]], [[Venezuela]], and studied at the Conservatorio de Musica [[Jose Angel Lamas]]. She later continued her studies in composition with William Banch, and in 1981 she attended [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana University]] in [[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington]] on a Venezuenlan government scholarship, graduating with bachelor's and master's degrees in composition.<ref>{{cite book |title=The new Grove dictionary of music and musicians|volume=15|editor=Tyrrell, John|author=Téllez, Carmen Helena|year=2001}}</ref>
Marchado returned to Venezuela, where she began work as a music teacher and composer. From 1987-88 she was a research assistant at the [[Rómulo Gallegos Center for Latin American Studies]] in Caracas. From 1989-93 she attended the [[University of Cincinnati – College-Conservatory of Music]], working as a teaching assistant, and graduated with a Doctor of Musical Arts degree in 1993.<ref name="composers">{{cite web |url=http://www.composersforum.org/members/directory/marianella-machado |title=Marianella Machado Biography |publisher=[[American Composers' Forum]] |accessdate=February 8, 2012 }}{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In 1994 Machado began pursuing an interest in Spanish as second language and Hispanic literature. She attended the Department of Romance Languages and Literatures of the University of Cincinnati on assistantship where she graduated with a Master of Arts in 1996 and a PhD in Hispanic Literature in 1998.
From 1998-2003 she worked as a professor at the [[Universidad Católica Andrés Bello]] in Caracas. In August 2003 she took a position as Assistant Professor of Spanish in the Department of Foreign Languages and Humanities at [[Eastern Kentucky University]] in the United States.<ref name="composers"/> <ref>{{cite book |title=A guide to the Latin American art song repertoire|first=Maya|last=Hoover|first2=Stela M.|last2=Brandão|first3=Ellie Anne|last3=Duque|date=2009}}</ref>
==Works== Selected works include: * ''Inmutable'' for French horn solo (2002) * ''Tonos Diamantinos No. 6'' for woodwind quartet (2003) * ''Remembranza'' for string orchestra (2004) * ''The Triumph of Love'' (2005) * ''Butterfly Triptych'' (2006)<ref>{{cite book |url= |title=Scores and recordings at the Indiana University Latin American Music Center|publisher=Indiana University, Bloomington Latin American Music Center|first=Ricardo|last=Lorenz|first2=Luis R.|last2= Hernández|date=1995}}</ref>
Machado has written a number of papers and articles, including ''Contra el secreto professional'' on Peruvian poet [[Cesar Vallejo]] for the Cincinnati Conference for Romance Languages and Literatures. She also published a review on the book ''Siete y tres nueve'' by Colombian writer [[Jose Cardona]] in the journal ''Chasqui'' at the [[University of Nebraska]].<ref>{{cite journal |title=Cardona López, José, Siete Y Tres Nueve|author=Machado, Marianella|journal=Chasqui|volume=33|year=2004}}</ref> She has written books including ''Encuentros Causales'' (2009) and ''Menudencias'' (2009).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://works.bepress.com/marianella_machado|title=SelectedWorks of Marianella P. Machado|accessdate=8 February 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Machado, Marianella}} [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century classical composers]] [[Category:Music educators]] [[Category:Female classical composers]] [[Category:Venezuelan composers]] [[Category:People from Caracas]] [[Category:Indiana University alumni]] [[Category:University of Cincinnati – College-Conservatory of Music alumni]] [[Category:20th-century women musicians]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox university |name = Michigan Technological University |image = Michigan Technological University seal.svg |image_size = 150 |motto = Create the Future |established = 1885 |type = [[Public university|Public]] |endowment = [[United States dollar|$]]96.2 million (2016){{cite web |url=http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/michigan-tech-2292 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-03-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150325103855/http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/michigan-tech-2292 |archivedate=March 25, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} |president = Richard J. Koubek |students = 7,270{{cite web| title = About Michigan Tech| url = http://www.mtu.edu/about/| accessdate = June 28, 2017| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170620054529/http://www.mtu.edu/about/| archivedate = June 20, 2017| df = mdy-all}} |undergrad = 5,827 |postgrad = 1,443 |faculty = 477{{cite web| title = About Michigan Tech| url = http://www.mtu.edu/about/| accessdate = June 28, 2017| deadurl = no| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20170620054529/http://www.mtu.edu/about/| archivedate = June 20, 2017| df = mdy-all}} |staff = 1,153 |city = [[Houghton, Michigan|Houghton]] |state = [[Michigan]] |country = U.S. |coor = {{Coord|47.12|-88.55|display=inline,title|type:edu}} |campus = {{convert|925|acre|km2}}, Rural |colors = Metallic Silver and Gold{{cite web| title = MTU Fast Facts| url=https://www.mtu.edu/about/|accessdate = 2018-11-18|deadurl = no}} |nickname = [[Michigan Tech Huskies|Huskies]] |mascot = [[Blizzard T. Husky]] |sporting_affiliations = [[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]
* [[NCAA Division II|Division II]] – [[Great Lakes Intercollegiate Athletic Conference|GLIAC]]
* [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] – [[Western Collegiate Hockey Association|WCHA]] |website = {{url|www.mtu.edu}} |logo = Michigan Technological University logo.svg |logo_size = 200 }} '''Michigan Technological University''' ('''Michigan Tech''', '''MTU''', or simply '''Tech''') is a [[public university|public]] [[research university]] in [[Houghton, Michigan]]. Its main campus sits on {{convert|925|acre|ha|0|sp=us}} on a bluff overlooking [[Keweenaw Waterway|Portage Lake]]. Michigan Tech was founded in 1885 as the first post-secondary institution in the [[Upper Peninsula of Michigan]] and was created to train mining engineers to operate the [[Copper mining in Michigan|local copper mines]]. Science, technology, forestry and business have been added to the numerous engineering disciplines, and Michigan Tech now offers more than 130 degree programs through its five colleges and schools. Michigan Tech's athletic teams are nicknamed the [[Michigan Tech Huskies|Huskies]] and compete primarily in the [[NCAA Division II]] [[Great Lakes Intercollegiate Athletic Conference]] (GLIAC). The men's [[College ice hockey|hockey]] team competes in [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] as a member of the [[Western Collegiate Hockey Association]] (WCHA), and has won three national championships. The women's basketball team were national runners-up in 2011. ==History== [[Image:Michigan Mining School 1895 advertisement.jpg|thumb|175px|1895 advertisement for the Michigan Mining School]] Michigan Tech was founded in 1885 as the '''Michigan Mining School'''.{{cite web|title=Michigan Technological University History |url=http://www.mtu.edu/mtuinfo/history.html |accessdate=2008-01-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716024704/http://www.mtu.edu/mtuinfo/history.html |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df= }} After much agitation by [[Jay Abel Hubbell]], the state legislature established the school to train mining engineers. Hubbell donated land for the school's first buildings.Willis F. Dunbar and George S. May, ''Michigan: A History of the Wolverine State'' (Grand Rapids: Eerdman's, 1995), 359. The school started with four faculty members and twenty-three students. It was housed in the [[Houghton Fire Hall]] from 1886 through 1889.{{cite web|title=Houghton Fire Hall |url=http://www.mcgi.state.mi.us/hso/sites/5884.htm |work=State Historic Preservation Office |publisher=Michigan State Housing Development Authority |accessdate=January 13, 2012 |author=Staff |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130617141027/http://www.mcgi.state.mi.us/hso/sites/5884.htm |archivedate=June 17, 2013 |df= }} A few years after the school's creation, enrollment grew to such a point that its name no longer reflected its purpose. The name was then changed to the '''Michigan College of Mines''' in 1897.{{cite book|ref=harv|title=The sandstone architecture of the Lake Superior region|last=Eckert|first=Kathryn Bishop|authorlink=|coauthors=|year=2000|publisher=Wayne State University Press|location=|isbn=978-0-8143-2807-1|page=280|pages=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=b68xzUc0y3IC&pg=PA280|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160519182356/https://books.google.com/books?id=b68xzUc0y3IC&pg=PA280|archivedate=May 19, 2016|df=mdy-all}} This name lasted through World War I until 1925, but by this time the school had begun offering a wider variety of degrees and once again decided to change its name to the '''Michigan College of Mining and Technology''' in 1927. By 1931 enrollment had reached nearly 600. During the next few years, due to the Great Depression, money was scarce, causing department heads and even the president of the university, [[William O. Hotchkiss|William Hotchkiss]], to take pay cuts. Grover C. Dillman was president from 1935 to 1956. During this time, the school underwent many notable changes, including the construction of the Memorial Union Building and purchase of an ice rink and golf course. Around 1948, enrollment passed 2000 students total. In 1956, J. Robert Van Pelt became the new president of the university. He restarted many PhD programs and created a focus on research. This included the school's first analog computation class in 1956–1957.{{cite web|last=Waltman|first=Gene L.|title=Black Magic and Gremlins: Analog Flight Simulations at NASA's Flight Research Center|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2060/20010011952|work=NASA SP-2000-4520|publisher=NASA Technical Reports Server|accessdate=September 13, 2011}} In the final years of his presidency, the school changed from a college to a university, changing its name a final time to ''Michigan Technological University''. The change from the Michigan College of Mining and Technology was necessary for two reasons, according to Van Pelt. First, the college had expanded too greatly and the current name was no longer an accurate title. Also, including "mining" in the name of the college was misleading.{{cite web | title = Michigan Technological University: A History | url = http://www.sas.it.mtu.edu/urel/welcome/history.html | accessdate = 2010-03-30 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20120305135105/http://www.sas.it.mtu.edu/urel/welcome/history.html | archivedate = March 5, 2012 | df = mdy-all }} The name "Michigan Technological University" was chosen in order to retain the nickname "Michigan Tech" that had already been in use since 1927. Although engineering still accounts for some 59 percent of all enrollment as of fall 2010, the university now offers more than 130 degree programs. Along with its new name, the school also gained new constitutional status in 1964. This gave responsibility for control of the university to its Board of Control rather than the state legislature."Why a New Name and Constitutional Status for Michigan College of Mining and Technology" Vertical File: History- MTU-Name Change from MCMT to MTU. Michigan Tech Archives & Copper Country Historical Collections. File:Michigan School of Mines, Houghton, Mich..jpg|Michigan School of Mines, c.1906 File:Michigan School of Mines, Houghton, Mich.jpg|Michigan School of Mines, c.1906 File:Main building, Michigan School of Mines, Houghton, Mich..jpg|Main building, c.1906 File:Chemical laboratory, Michigan School of Mines, Houghton, Mich..jpg|Chemical laboratory, c.1906 File:Cirkut photo of Mining College, Houghton, Mich..jpg|Panorama, c.1910 ==Campus== {{Main|Campus of Michigan Technological University}} The main Michigan Tech campus is located mainly on [[U.S. Route 41 in Michigan|US 41]] in Houghton, Michigan. It is the safest campus in Michigan, and the third safest in the United States, according to ''Reader's Digest''.{{cite web | title = Ranking of the Safest (and Least Secured) campuses | url = http://www.rd.com/family/ranking-the-safest-and-worst-college-campuses/ | accessdate = June 23, 2011 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110822181744/http://www.rd.com/family/ranking-the-safest-and-worst-college-campuses/ | archivedate = August 22, 2011 | df = mdy-all }} The main part of campus is relatively small, and can be traversed in about 10 minutes. The offices of the Michigan Tech Fund are located in the Huntington Bank Building in Hancock.[http://www.admin.mtu.edu/rbb.html A to Z | Michigan Technological University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100613151918/http://www.admin.mtu.edu/rbb.html |date=June 13, 2010 }}. Admin.mtu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-16. The Lakeshore Center in downtown Houghton houses the offices of Human Relations, Vice President for Research and other departments.{{Cite web|url=https://events.mtu.edu/lakeshore_center#.Wr3INy7wZhE|title=Lakeshore Center|website=Michigan Tech Events Calendar|language=en|access-date=2018-03-30}} Faculty are involved in several [[distance education]] programs with clients including [[General Motors Corporation|General Motors]]. The Portage Lake Golf Course opened for play in April 1902. In 1945 the members could no longer support the needs of the course and sold it to Michigan Tech for one dollar. Since then many improvements have been made such as the addition of another nine holes in 1969. Then in 1984 the new clubhouse was constructed. In 1996 a sprinkler system was installed to modernize the course and keep it playable. The Portage Lake Golf Course is located two miles (3 km) southeast of campus. ==Academics== {{Refimprove section|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox US university ranking | ARWU_W = | ARWU_N = | Forbes =492 | QS_W = | TARU = | THES_W = | USNWR_NU = 116 | USNWR_LA = | USNWR_REG= | Wamo_NU =68{{cite web|title=2014 National Universities Rankings |date=n.d. |accessdate=May 25, 2015 |website=Washington Monthly |url=http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings-2014/national-universities-rank-all.php |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140828025627/http://www.washingtonmonthly.com/college_guide/rankings-2014/national-universities-rank-all.php |archivedate=August 28, 2014 |df= }} | Wamo_LA = }} Michigan Tech offers more than 130 undergraduate and graduate degrees in engineering, [[natural science|natural]] and [[physical science]]s, computing, business and economics, technology, environmental studies, arts, humanities, and social sciences. The university is divided into five schools and colleges. The average overall ACT scores for incoming students is 27.2 in fall 2017,{{cite web|url=http://www.mtu.edu/umc/resources/facts/|title=Michigan Tech Fast Facts|last=|first=|date=|website=|accessdate=07/08/2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170627224815/http://www.mtu.edu/umc/resources/facts/|archivedate=June 27, 2017|df=mdy-all}} compared to 21.2 nationally. It currently has the highest tuition of all public universities in Michigan, exceeding both Michigan State and the University of Michigan.{{cite web | title = College Tuition Costs | url = http://www.collegecalc.org/lists/michigan/most-expensive-in-state-tuition/?start=21 | accessdate = November 20, 2015 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151121074643/http://www.collegecalc.org/lists/michigan/most-expensive-in-state-tuition/?start=21 | archivedate = November 21, 2015 | df = mdy-all }} The College of Engineering's environmental engineering and mechanical engineering enrollments rank in the top ten nationally[http://www.doe.mtu.edu/ College of Engineering | Michigan Technological University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070223075744/http://www.doe.mtu.edu/ |date=February 23, 2007 }}. Doe.mtu.edu (2013-02-19). Retrieved on 2013-08-16. and their respective graduate programs are ranked in the top 50 in the US. The electrical engineering department uses an innovative "[[digital signal processing|DSP]] First" curriculum found at only a few leading universities.[http://www.ece.mtu.edu/pages/academics/BSEE.html/ Electrical Engineering BS Degree | Electrical and Computer Engineering] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100606223947/http://www.ece.mtu.edu/pages/academics/BSEE.html |date=June 6, 2010 }}. Ece.mtu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-16. *'''The College of Engineering'''. Its departments are biomedical engineering, civil and environmental engineering, mechanical engineering-engineering mechanics, electrical and computer engineering, chemical engineering, materials science and engineering, and geological and mining engineering and sciences.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtu.edu/engineering/undergraduate/majors/|title=College of Engineering Majors {{!}} Michigan Technological University|website=www.mtu.edu|access-date=2016-09-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160902044838/http://www.mtu.edu/engineering/undergraduate/majors/|archivedate=September 2, 2016|df=mdy-all}} *'''The College of Sciences and Arts''' has majors in fields including bio-informatics, biological sciences, biochemistry, [[cheminformatics]], chemistry, computer science, kinesiology and integrative physiology, mathematics, pharmaceutical chemistry, physics, psychology, and social sciences.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtu.edu/registrar/students/major-degree/audit/sciarts/|title=College of Sciences & Arts Audits {{!}} The Registrar's Office|website=www.mtu.edu|access-date=2016-09-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160908014115/http://www.mtu.edu/registrar/students/major-degree/audit/sciarts/|archivedate=September 8, 2016|df=mdy-all}} It includes one of the largest technical [[Communication studies|communications]] programs in the United States.{{Cite news|url=https://www.infomanagementcenter.com/publications/best-practices-newsletter/1999-best-practices-newsletter/michigan-technological-university/|title=Michigan Technological University|work=CIDM|access-date=2017-04-01|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402082259/https://www.infomanagementcenter.com/publications/best-practices-newsletter/1999-best-practices-newsletter/michigan-technological-university/|archivedate=April 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtu.edu/humanities/undergraduate/stc/|title=Scientific & Technical Communication | Humanities | Michigan Tech|website=www.mtu.edu|language=en|access-date=2017-04-01|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170402083207/http://www.mtu.edu/humanities/undergraduate/stc/|archivedate=April 2, 2017|df=mdy-all}}{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} The College is also home to the education, theater, Air Force ROTC, and Army ROTC programs. *'''The School of Business and Economics''' is accredited by [[AACSB]]. Students can receive a bachelor of science degree in seven areas, including accounting, economics, finance, management, management information systems, marketing, and operations and systems management. The undergraduate program includes a unique Business Development Experience, where students gain real-life business experience in a mentored environment.{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} Students also have the opportunity to join several business student organizations, including the Applied Portfolio Management Program where they invest $1 million in the stock market each year.{{Cite web|url=https://www.mtu.edu/business/student-engagement/apmp/|title=Real Investment—Applied Portfolio Management Program - APMP {{!}} School of Business & Economics|last=|first=|date=|website=www.mtu.edu|publisher=|access-date=2016-09-08|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160917012043/https://www.mtu.edu/business/student-engagement/apmp/|archivedate=September 17, 2016|df=mdy-all}} *'''The School of Forest Resources and Environmental Science''' has been recognized nationally for excellence in its research program, and its PhD program was ranked fourth in the nation by Academic Analytics in 2007.{{cite web |title = Academic Analytics |url = http://www.academicanalytics.com/ |deadurl = no |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080822232018/http://www.academicanalytics.com/TopSchools/TopSchools.aspx |archivedate = August 22, 2008 |df = mdy-all }} The School maintains greenhouses, labs, and the {{convert|4,000|acre|km2|adj=on}} Ford Forest and Ford Center in nearby Alberta, and celebrated its 75th year in 2011. *'''The School of Technology''' includes degree programs in Computer Networks and System Administration, Electrical Engineering Technology, Mechanical Engineering Technology, Surveying Engineering, Construction Management, and Industrial Technology.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtu.edu/technology/|title=School of Technology|website=www.mtu.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-03-30}} Michigan Tech has also developed an alternative program to provide students with engineering and other design experience called the Enterprise program. Enterprises develop engineering skills by allowing students to work in business-like environments on real-world projects while completing their education. Enterprises include Nanotechnology Innovations, Hybrid Transportation, Aerospace, Blue Marble Security, Husky Game Development, Boardsports Technologies, and Wireless Communications Enterprises.[http://www.enterprise.mtu.edu The Enterprise Program | Michigan Technological University] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061214063223/http://www.enterprise.mtu.edu/ |date=December 14, 2006 }}. Enterprise.mtu.edu. Retrieved on 2013-08-16. ===Student body=== The student body consists of more than 7,000 graduate and undergraduate students (Fall 2017) and more than 470 academic faculty (Fall 2017). As is historically true of engineering institutions, female enrollment at Michigan Tech is low. The male to female student ratio was 22:1 in 1960; since 1980 it has remained around 3:1. Michigan Tech's admissions office has enlisted female students and faculty to contact every admitted female applicant via telephone or personal letter in an attempt to increase female enrollment. The Fall 2010 freshman class had a ratio of 3.1:1. In the Fall 2012 semester, female enrollment rose for the 6th straight year to reach a then all-time high of 1,837 students (26.1%).{{cite journal|author=Goodrich, Marcia |date=Fall 2009 |title=Where the Boys Are |magazine=Michigan Tech Magazine |volume=46 |issue=2 |publisher=Michigan Technological University |location=Houghton, MI |url=http://www.mtu.edu/umc/services/pr-news/magazine/fall09/stories/where-the-boys-are/ |accessdate=July 21, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60LQeQqHh?url=http://www.mtu.edu/umc/services/pr-news/magazine/fall09/stories/where-the-boys-are/ |archivedate=July 21, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Female enrollment for the 2017-2018 academic year is 27.1%.{{Cite news|url=http://www.mtu.edu/news/stories/2017/september/tech-marks-fifth-straight-year-enrollment-increases.html|title=Tech Marks Fifth Straight Year of Enrollment Increases|work=Michigan Technological University|access-date=2018-03-30|language=en}} Michigan Tech students are primarily from Michigan, Wisconsin, Minnesota, and Illinois. The student body is approximately 75.4% European-American/Non-Hispanic, 14.2% International, 1.6% Hispanic, 1.5% percent African American, 1.0% Asian, 0.6% Native American, 1.0% Multiracial, 0.1% Pacific Islander, and the remaining 4.5% was not supplied. The university has recently focused on achieving a more diverse student body, in terms of ethnicity, gender, and areas of study. A key step in this effort was the recent introduction of several new [[academic major]]s, including psychology, biochemistry and molecular biology, [[cheminformatics]], communication and culture studies, pharmaceutical chemistry, exercise science, sound design, audio production, and theater and entertainment technology. ===Research=== Michigan Tech ranked 172nd of 600 US colleges and universities in research and development expenditures in 2007.{{cite web|title=Center for Measuring University Performance 2009 Annual Report |url=http://mup.asu.edu/research2009.pdf |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100601070708/http://mup.asu.edu/research2009.pdf |archivedate=June 1, 2010 |df= }} Research expenditures exceeded $50 million in 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.mtu.edu/stratplan/dashboard/|title=Michigan Tech Dashboard|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=07/08/2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170715090122/http://www.mtu.edu/stratplan/dashboard/|archivedate=July 15, 2017|df=mdy-all}} ==Student life== [[File:2009-0617-MTU-MemorialUnion.jpg|thumb|300x300px|[[Memorial Union Building (MTU)|Memorial Union]]]] Students attending Michigan Technological University have a wide range of activities to participate in, whether or not they are living in the [[residence halls]]. In addition to the various small interest groups which form throughout the year, they participate in [[Greek Life]], Student Organizations, and the Enterprise Program; many organize and attend campus traditions, such as K-Day, the Parade of Nations, and the Winter Carnival (which also attracts alumni from across the country); furthermore, there are motivational drives to raise student activity levels and involvement in the school community, typically for those without membership in a student organization. ===Student organizations=== [[File:Broomball at Michigan Tech.jpg|alt=Students playing broomball|thumb|300x300px|Michigan Tech Students playing [[broomball]]]] Michigan Tech currently recognizes more than two hundred student organizations,[http://www.sa.mtu.edu/stulife/stuorg/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120515082105/http://www.sa.mtu.edu/stulife/stuorg/|date=May 15, 2012}} including: * ''The Daily Bull'', satirical daily entertainment press newspaper; often prints current campus and world news in some form or other{{cite web |url=http://dailybull.students.mtu.edu/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130430044004/http://dailybull.students.mtu.edu/ |archivedate=April 30, 2013 |df=mdy-all }} * [[Alpha Phi Omega]], Epsilon Lambda chapter, national co-ed service fraternity * ''Mushing Club at Michigan Tech'', The first and only university mushing (dog sledding) club in the US. Founded in 2018 by student mushers, Adam Schmidt and Claire Hendricks. * [[Mu Beta Psi]], Zeta chapter, national honorary musical fraternity * The Alpha (first) chapter of [[Alpha Sigma Mu]], nationwide metallurgical and [[materials engineering]] honors fraternity * Blue Key, an affiliate of the National Blue Key honor society, which organizes the annual [[Michigan Technological University's Winter Carnival|Winter Carnival]] * The pride of Pastyland, the cream of the Keweenaw, the second best feeling in the world, the [[Huskies Pep Band]].{{cite web |url=http://dawgs.students.mtu.edu/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-12-09 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210215556/http://dawgs.students.mtu.edu/ |archivedate=December |accessdate=2011-03-21 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303063635/http://www.mtulode.com/ |archivedate=March 3, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} * Undergraduate Student station{{Cite web|url=https://wmtu.fm/|title=WMTU 91.9-FM Houghton|website=wmtu.fm|access-date=2018-03-30}} * Film Board, screens theatrical features at a low cost to students and other members of the Michigan Tech community{{cite web |url=http://filmboard.mtu.edu/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-12 |deadurl=no
