revision.text:
[[File:Stavanger Museum.JPG|thumb|Stavanger Museum]] '''Stavanger Museum''' is a museum of natural and cultural history established in 1877, located in the Norwegian city [[Stavanger]]. The museum's collections consist of several departments: the department of zoology, the department for cultural history (which also includes custodianship of the royal residence [[Ledaal]]).
Departments include the Stavanger Museum of Natural History, Stavanger Maritime Museum, Norwegian Children's Museum, Norwegian Printing Museum, Stavanger School Museum, Stavanger Art Museum, and Norwegian Canning Museum.<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007 |title=Stavanger Museum |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]] |first=Lauritz |last=Opstad |authorlink=Lauritz Opstad|editor=Henriksen, Petter |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo |url=http://www.snl.no/Stavanger_Museum |language=Norwegian |accessdate=14 October 2009 }}</ref><ref name=byleks-stavangermuseum>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2008 |title=Stavanger Museum |encyclopedia=Stavanger byleksikon |publisher=Wigestrand |location=Stavanger |language=Norwegian }}</ref> [[File:Ledaal-Stavanger.jpg|thumb|Ledaal royal residence]] [[File:Breidablikk.jpg|thumb|Breidablikk villa]]
==History== Stavanger Museum was founded in 1877, and was first located in a small wooden house in [[Gamle Stavanger]]. The museum got its own building, Muségata 3, in 1893, designed by architect [[Hartvig Sverdrup Eckhoff]]. The building was extended in 1930, and again in 1964. A major restoration and technical upgrade was performed in 1995.<ref name=byleks-stavangermuseum/>
[[Ledaal]], the summer house of the Kielland family built by [[Gabriel Schanche Kielland]], was bought by Stavanger Museum in 1936, and opened as a royal residence in 1949.<ref name=ledaal>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007 |title=Ledaal |encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]] |editor=Henriksen, Petter |publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget |location=Oslo |url=http://www.snl.no/Ledaal |language=Norwegian |accessdate=19 October 2009 }}</ref> The royal residence Ledaal dates from around 1800. Breidablikk villa is a well-preserved mansion which was built in 1881-1882 for the merchant and ship owner [[Lars Berentsen]] (1838-1896) . The villa was designed by architect [[Henrik Nissen]]. Breidablikk villa is situated on [[Eiganes]] in Stavanger.<ref>[http://www.museumstavanger.no/museums/breidablikk/about-breidablikk/ ''Breidablikk'' (Museum Stavanger)]</ref>
The archeological department was split out in 1975, as the new institution ''Arkeologisk museum i Stavanger''. The Maritime Museum was included in 1979.<ref name=snl/> The Graphical museum was established in 1991, and included in Stavanger Museum in 2006. The Children's Museum was established in 2000, and incorporated as a department of Stavanger Museum in 2007. The school museum was established in 1925, and incorporated into Stavanger Museum in 2008. The department also incorporates ''Den Kombinerede Indretning'', a collection of local medical history established in 1989, and a part of Stavanger Museum from 2006.<ref name=byleks-stavangermuseum/>
[[File:Day mark Jaerens Rev.jpg|thumb|right |200px|Revtangen Ornithological Station]]
==Stavanger Museum of Natural History== Stavanger Museum of Natural History (''Stavanger naturhistoriske museum'') was formerly the Department of Zoology at the Stavanger Museum. The department of zoology was central to the establishing of the museum in 1877, assigned the task of collecting local fauna, and also "exotic" mammals and birds donated by sailors and travelers. From 1918 the museum specialized in ornithological research. Revtangen Ornithological Station is located in an area known for its rich and varied bird life. Stavanger Museum has a station here where migratory birds are tagged or ringed each year. The ornithological station for [[bird ringing]] was established in 1937 and is operated by the museum.<ref name=byleks-stavangermuseum/><ref>[http://www.museumstavanger.no/museums/stavanger-museum-natural-history-/bird-ringing-centre/ ''Revtangen Ringing Centre'' (Museum Stavanger)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151017055040/http://www.museumstavanger.no/museums/stavanger-museum-natural-history-/bird-ringing-centre/ |date=2015-10-17 }}</ref>
==Stavanger Maritime Museum== The Maritime Museum was established in 1926 and included as a department of Stavanger Museum from 1979. Until 1984 the exhibitions were at Stavanger Museum's main building in Muségata 16, and were moved to historical locations at the port of Stavanger (Nedre Strandgate 17 and 19) in 1985. The buildings are from the period 1770 to 1840. The exhibition displays the development of the shipping and fishing industry over the last 200 years. The museum owns and operates two older sailboats, ''Anna af Sand'' from 1848 and ''[[Wyvern (vessel)|Wyvern]]'' from 1896.<ref name=byleks-maritime>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2008 |title=Stavanger Sjøfartsmuseum |encyclopedia=Stavanger byleksikon |publisher=Wigestrand |location=Stavanger |language=Norwegian }}</ref> [[File:Norsk barnemuseum.jpg|thumb|200px|Norwegian Children's Museum]]
==Norwegian Children's Museum== Norwegian Children's Museum (''Norsk Barnemuseum'') began as a private foundation and opened doors to the public 24 November 2001. The museum is located in the Stavanger Cultural Centre on Arneageren.
==Norwegian Printing Museum== Norwegian Printing Museum (''Norsk Grafisk Museum'') was established in 1991. Stavanger has always been a center of gravity in the Norwegian printing industry. The museum is located on [[Bjergsted]] in Stavanger, and is housed in an old canning stock dating from 1913. The premises are renovated and restored to original condition. Norwegian Printing Museum was officially opened on 23 October 1993.
==Stavanger School Museum== Stavanger School Museum (''Stavanger skolemuseum'') was formerly the Vestlandske Skolemuseum. The museum school is located in a schoolhouse from the 1920s in [[Hillevåg]]. The museum which opened in 1925, covers the history of the school in Rogaland. There is a curriculum with role play and dressing up in the school's historic environment.
==Stavanger Art Museum== Stavanger Art Museum (''Stavanger kunstmuseum'') was formerly the Rogaland Museum of Fine Arts. The museum is located on the west side of the lake at Tjensvoll in Stavanger. Stavanger Art Museum opened in 1991. The museum has an extensive collection of more than two thousand works by Norwegian and international art from the 1800s to the present day. Works by [[Lars Hertervig]] constitutes a center of gravity, with more than 70 watercolors and oil paintings. Other Norwegian artists from 1800 - and 1900's are represented [[Kitty Kielland]], [[Edvard Munch]], [[Christian Krogh]], [[Eilif Petersen]], [[Knut Baade]], [[Olaf Lange]], [[Carl Sundt-Hansen]] and [[Harriet Backer]].
[[File:Norsk hermetikkmuseum.jpg|thumb|right |200px|Norwegian Canning Museum]]
==Norwegian Canning Museum== The Norwegian Canning Museum (''Norsk Hermetikkmuseum'') was established in 1975, and is located in a preserved [[cannery]] in [[Gamle Stavanger]], Øvre Strandgate 88 and 90. The oldest parts of the building are from 1841; canning production here lasted from 1916 to mid-1950s. The exhibitions show machinery, tools, photographs, labels and commercials from the canning industry.<ref name=byleks-canning>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2008 |title=Norsk Hermetikkmuseum |encyclopedia=Stavanger byleksikon |publisher=Wigestrand |location=Stavanger |language=Norwegian }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://archive.is/20140624172306/http://www.museumstavanger.no/hjem/ Museum Stavanger website] {{commons category| Museum Stavanger}} {{coord|58|57|53|N|5|43|59|E|type:landmark_source:kolossus-nowiki|display=title}}
[[Category:Museums in Stavanger]] [[Category:Museums in Rogaland]] [[Category:Natural history museums in Norway]] [[Category:Museums established in 1877]] [[Category:Maritime museums in Norway]] [[Category:Children's museums]] [[Category:Industry museums in Norway]] [[Category:Art museums and galleries in Norway]] [[Category:Education museums]] [[Category:Printing press museums]] [[Category:Child-related organisations based in Norway]]

revision.comment: not a reliable source
revision.text:
'''Student teaching''' is a college-supervised instructional experience; usually the culminating course in a university or college [[undergraduate education]] or [[graduate school]] program leading to [[teacher education]] and certification. Examples of programs include Early Childhood (Birth-Grade 3), Middle Childhood (Grades 4-9), and Adolescence to Young Adult (Grades 7-12). It is required by those earning either a [[Bachelor of Education]] or [[Master of Education]] degree, as well as liberal arts [[Bachelor of Science]] or [[Bachelor of Arts]] degrees with a major in education.
Student teaching is required for students who are not yet certified to teach. It is different from a [[practicum]], which is required when a student ''already'' holds certification to teach, yet wants a certificate extension to teach another area of specialization; they are both college-supervised field-based experiences.
The student teaching experience lasts about the length of a semester or quarter; long enough to fulfill the college’s assigned tasks. It is an unpaid [[internship]]. This experience gives the prospective teaching professional an opportunity to teach under the supervision of a permanently certified master teacher (see [[schoolmaster]]).
The student teacher is usually placed in a neighboring or participating school. The student teacher is monitored by the cooperating teacher from the school, as well as a supervisor through the college. The supervisor acts as a liaison between the cooperating teacher and the head of the college’s student teaching department.
The student teacher normally shadows the cooperating teacher for about one week, eventually gaining more responsibility in teaching the class as the days and weeks progress. Eventually, the student teacher will assume most of the teaching responsibilities for the class including class management, lesson planning, assessment, and grading. Thus, the student teacher is able to more fully experience the role of the teacher as the classroom teacher takes on the observation role in the class. There is sometimes a "phasing out" week when the student teacher returns the teaching role back to the regular teacher.
The supervisor, as well as cooperating teacher, monitor the progress of the student teacher throughout the experience, ensuring ''satisfactory'' work. A grade of ''Pass'' or ''Fail'' in student teaching, as well as satisfactory completion of a school's education program, is an indication as to whether the college recommends the student for certification to teach.
==Student teaching as a learning challenge== Student teaching has been used as a challenge to foreign language learners to facilitate the integration of their language skills by placing them at the center of classroom activities.<ref>[http://iteslj.org/Techniques/Ogawa-StudentsTeach.html Ogawa & Wilkinson - Let Your Students Teach Their Class (I-TESL-J)]</ref>
Student teaching philosophy has proven to be a decisive between the newer cohort of teachers, and older educators. Trained under differing teaching philosophies, both groups have a difference of opinion on instructional methodology. The two most prevalent teaching philosophies in America are called Modern teaching philosophy and Traditional teaching philosophy respectively. The former relies on inquiry-based instruction, while the later relies heavily on lecture-based teaching. The differing of philosophies is being seen at every rung of the educational ladder, from Pre-K to Collegiate instruction.
In describing the difference between the two methodologies, one can note characteristics that define them. In traditional teaching methods, there is a high emphasis on attending lectures, reading texts, and solving problems. In modern teaching approaches, there is a high premium put on developing one's unique knowledge through the pursuit of the scientific method, using such didactic methods as observation and hypothesis.<ref>[http://eujournal.org/index.php/esj/article/download/1885/1827 Traditional Teaching Methods Vs. Teaching through the Application of Information]</ref>
Another hallmark of the modern teaching approach is the incorporation of technology, a highly useful skill that is required of most who intend on entering the job market in future years.<ref>[http://is.muni.cz/th/86952/ff_m_b1/MgrDiplomkaBoumova.pdf Traditional Vs. Modern Teaching Methods: Advantages and Disadvantages]</ref>
Examples of technological inclusion within the classroom has become supported in many counties through the United States. Most schools are equipped with smart boards and include roaming laptop carts that allow all students, regardless of financial ability, gain experience with the technology that will make them successful in the next steps of their lives.<ref>[http://education.mit.edu/papers/GamesSimsSocNets_EdArcade.pdf Using the Technology of Today, in the Classroom of Today]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Teacher training]]

'''The Chartered College of Teaching''', is the recognised professional body for the teaching profession. The college was founded in 1846 and incorporated by [[royal charter]] as '''The College of Preceptors''' in 1849.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://privycouncil.independent.gov.uk/wp-content/uploads/2018/09/2018-09-20-Record-of-Charters-Granted.xlsx|title=Privy Council: Record of Charters Granted 20th September 2018.|last=|first=|date=20 Sep 2018|website=Privy Council|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> A supplemental charter was granted in 1998 changing the College's name to '''The College of Teachers'''. A further supplemental charter granted in 2017 changed the college's name to '''The Chartered College of Teaching''', updated its objects and gave it the right to award the professional status of '''Chartered Teacher''' ('''CTeach''').<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://chartered.college/our-royal-charter|title=Our Royal Charter - The Chartered College of Teaching|work=The Chartered College of Teaching|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en-US}}</ref> The college's Patron is [[Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh|HRH The Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh]].
==History== The college was founded in 1846 by a group of private schoolmasters from [[Brighton]] who were concerned about standards within their profession.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160324095730/http://www.collegeofteachers.ac.uk/about/history Archive|Our history The College of Teachers]</ref> A provisional committee was set up in early 1846 under the chairmanship of Henry Stein Turrell (1815–1863), principal of the Montpelier House School in Brighton. After meetings in London and Brighton a general meeting was called for 20 June 1846 at the Freemason's Tavern in Great Queen Street. Some 300 schoolmasters attended, some 60 members enrolled and founding resolutions passed, including:
:That in the opinion of this meeting, it is desirable for the protection of the interests of both the scholastic profession and the public, that some proof of qualification, both as to the amount of knowledge and the art of conveying it to others, should be required, from and after a certain time to be hereinafter specified, of all persons who may be desirous of entering the profession; and that the test, in the first instance, should be applied to Assistant Masters only. :That in the opinion of this meeting, the test of qualification should be referred to a legally authorised or corporate body, or college, consisting of persons engaged in tuition. :That for the purpose of effecting this object – viz., the formation of a corporate body – the members of the profession who enrol their names at this meeting, do resolve themselves, and are hereby resolved, into the College of Preceptors; and that those persons now enrolled, shall incur no liability beyond the amount of their respective annual subscriptions. :That a Council, consisting of the members of the Provisional Committee, with power to add to their number, be now appointed for the purpose of conducting the business of the institution, and that Mr Turrell be appointed President of the Council.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Aldrich|first1=Richard|title=School and Society in Victorian Britain: Joseph Payne and the New World of Education|date=16 May 2012|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0415686532|pages=96–98}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=College of Preceptors|url=http://www.ucl.ac.uk/bloomsbury-project/institutions/college_preceptors.htm|website=UCL Bloomsbury Project|publisher=UCL|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Ashton|first1=Rosemary|title=Victorian Bloomsbury|date=2012|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=978-0300154474|pages=454-46}}</ref>
The college created a system for the formal examination and qualification of secondary school teachers. It was also one of the first bodies to examine and provide certificates for secondary school pupils of both sexes, from all over [[England]] and [[Wales]], in a wide variety of subjects.<ref>{{cite web | title = Institute of Education Archives: DC/COP Records of the College of Preceptors. | publisher = Institute of Education | url = http://www.ioe.ac.uk/services/957.html | accessdate = 2009-04-01 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160303235021/http://www.ioe.ac.uk/services/957.html | archivedate = 2016-03-03 | dead-url = yes }}</ref> In 1873 it became the first institution to appoint Professors of Education,
During the 1870s, the college helped to establish education as a subject worthy of study at [[university]] level, resulting in the appointment of [[Joseph Payne]] as the first [[Professor]] of [[Education]] in 1873. The power to appoint [[Professor|Professors]] of [[Education]] is recognised in the college's current [[royal charter]].<ref name=":0" />[[Frances Mary Buss|Frances Buss]] (1827–1894) and [[Sir John Adams]] (1857–1934) were also connected to the College. During the 1950s the college pioneered [[management]] training schemes for teachers (at the time these were known as school administration courses).
On 21 February 1981, the College was granted armorial bearings. Until 2016, the college awarded a range of professional qualifications for teachers aligned to university qualifications up to and including Doctoral Fellowship.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://chartered.college/legal|title=Regulations - The Chartered College of Teaching|last=|first=|date=|work=The Chartered College of Teaching|access-date=2018-10-20|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Objects === Under the 1849 Charter, the objects of the college were:
''<nowiki/>'promoting sound learning and of advancing the interests of education more especially among the middle Classes by affording facilities to the Teacher for the acquiring of a sound knowledge of his Profession and by providing for the Periodical Session of a competent Board of Examiners to ascertain and give Certificates of the acquirements and fitness for their office of persons engaged or desiring to be engaged in the Education of Youth particularly in the Private Schools of England and Wales'''
The current objects of the college, since 2017, are:
''<nowiki/>'the promotion of sound learning and the improvement and recognition of the art, science and practice of teaching for the public benefit'''<ref name=":0" />
===Journals=== * ''The Educational Times'' published 1847–1923 *''Education Today'' published quarterly until December 2016 *''Impact'' published termly from May 2017<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://apps.charitycommission.gov.uk/Accounts/Ends08/0000313608_AC_20170630_E_C.pdf|title=Annual Report of the The Chartered College of Teaching for the year ended 30th June 2017.|last=|first=|date=20 Sep 2018|website=Charity Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
===Books=== * {{ cite book | last = College of Preceptors | title = Fifty years of progress in education : a review of the work of the College of Preceptors from its foundation in 1846 to its jubilee in 1896 | publisher = College of Preceptors | date = 1896 | location = London}}
==Membership designations==
The Chartered College of Teaching has the following membership designations or post-nominals.<ref>[https://chartered.college/our-offer-to-members Chartered College Membership]</ref> These include:
* MCCT - NQT Membership * MCCT - Full Membership * FCCT - Fellowship
Fellowship of the college, must be nominated by a peer, and is based on the following criteria:
* Must hold high academic and educational oriented qualifications; * Must be senior teachers of at least ten years standing; * Must have made a significant contribution to the teaching profession; and/or * Must serve in educational management at a senior level.
'''Historic Affiliates'''
This is a closed category of membership, consisting of those members continuing in the grade of membership they previously held in the College of Teachers, whose membership of the College of Teachers dates from before 1st September 2015.<ref>[https://chartered.college/membership-handbook Chartered College Membership Handbook]</ref>
* Associate Member of the College of Teachers (AMCollT) * Member of the College of Teachers (MCollT or MCollP) * Fellow of the College of Teachers (FCollT or FCollP)
==Primary sources== The archives of the college are held in the archives of the Institute of Education, University of London and the full catalogue can be found [http://archive.ioe.ac.uk/DServe/dserve.exe?dsqIni=Dserve.ini&dsqApp=Archive&dsqDb=Catalog&dsqCmd=NaviTree.tcl&dsqField=RefNo&dsqItem=COP#HERE online here].
==Other sources==
* American Association for the Advancement of Science. 1887. The London College of Preceptors. Moses King, v.9:471. * Balfour, Graham. 1903. The Educational Systems of Great Britain and Ireland. Clarendon Press, 185. * Eve. H.W. 1899. Secondary Education and the Primary Examinations. British Medical Journal. Published by British Medical Association. vol.1:123. * Chapman, J. Vincent. 1985, Professional Roots: The College of Preceptors in British Society. Theydon Bois Epping. * College of Preceptors. 1847. The Mechanics' Magazine. Original from Oxford University, 443-46, 485–90. * College of Preceptors. 1908. Journal of the Royal Society of Arts. Royal Society of Arts (Great Britain), published for the Society by George Bell, v.57 1908–09, 432. * College of Preceptors. 1895. Report of the Commissioners ... Great Britain Royal Commission on Secondary Education. Great Britain:H.M. Stationery Off., by Eyre and Spottiswoode, 58. * Montgomery, Robert John. 1967. College of Preceptors. Examinations: An Account of Their Evolution as Administrative Devices in England. University of Pittsburgh Press, 303. * Monroe, Paul. 1913. Preceptors, The College of. A Cyclopedia of Education. Gale Research Co., v.5:26. * The Teacher's Registration Bill. 1891. Hansard's Parliamentary Debates. Great Britain Parliament, Thomas Curson Hansard. v.350 1891 Feb–Mar, 1003. * Winnipeg Science Fiction Society, Royal Society of Arts (Great Britain). 1873. The College of Preceptors. Winnipeg, v. 21:893.

revision.text:
{{Good article}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:''Theme Hospital''}} {{Use British English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Infobox video game | title = Theme Hospital | image = Theme Hospital.front cover.jpg | caption = North American PC cover art | developer = [[Bullfrog Productions]] (PC)
[[Krisalis Software]] (PS) | publisher = [[Electronic Arts]] | designer = Mark Webley | artist = [[Gary Carr (video game developer)|Gary Carr]] | producer = [[Mark Webley]] | writer = James Leach
Sean Masterson
Neil Cook | platforms = [[Personal computer|PC]], [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] | released = '''PC'''
{{vgrelease|WW|31 March 1997}} '''PlayStation'''
{{Video game release|EU|February 1998|NA|31 March 1998|JP|18 June 1998{{cite web|title=テーマホスピタル|trans-title=Theme Hospital|url=https://store.playstation.com/#!/ja-jp/%e3%82%b2%e3%83%bc%e3%83%a0/%e3%83%86%e3%83%bc%e3%83%9e%e3%83%9b%e3%82%b9%e3%83%94%e3%82%bf%e3%83%ab/cid=JP0006-NPJJ00299_00-0000000000000001|website=PlayStation Store|publisher=Sony|accessdate=6 October 2016|language=Japanese|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6hLz2LwKJ?url=https://store.playstation.com/#!/ja-jp/%e3%82%b2%e3%83%bc%e3%83%a0/%e3%83%86%e3%83%bc%e3%83%9e%e3%83%9b%e3%82%b9%e3%83%94%e3%82%bf%e3%83%ab/cid=JP0006-NPJJ00299_00-0000000000000001|archive-date=8 May 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}}} | genre = [[Business simulation game|Business simulation]] | modes = [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] | composer = [[Russell Shaw (composer)|Russell Shaw]]
Tony Cox }} '''''Theme Hospital''''' is a [[business simulation game]] developed by [[Bullfrog Productions]] and published by [[Electronic Arts]] in 1997 for the PC in which players design and operate a privately owned [[hospital]] with the goal of curing patients of fictitious comical ailments. The game is the thematic successor to ''[[Theme Park (video game)|Theme Park]]'', also produced by Bullfrog, and the second instalment in their ''Theme'' series, and part of their ''Designer Series''. The game is noted for its humour, and contains numerous references to pop culture. [[Peter Molyneux]] and James Leach came up with the idea of creating a ''Theme'' game based on a hospital, but Molyneux was not directly involved in development due to his work on ''[[Dungeon Keeper]]''. Designers originally planned to include four distinct gameplay modes corresponding to historical time periods, but this was dropped due to time pressures on the team. Multiplayer support with up to four players was added in a patch. The game received a generally positive reception, with reviewers praising the graphics and humour in particular. ''Theme Hospital'' was a commercial success, selling over 4 million copies worldwide, and was ported to the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] in 1998. A [[Sega Saturn]] version was in development, but cancelled. The game was re-released on [[GOG.com]] in 2012 and [[Origin (digital distribution software)|Origin]] in 2015, and the PlayStation version was released on the [[PlayStation Network]] in Europe in 2008, Japan in 2009, and North America in 2010. Revival attempts have been made with the development of [[open source video game|open-source]] remakes such as ''CorsixTH''. == Gameplay == [[File:ThemeHospital.gif|thumb|left|A typical hospital.]] The player is required to build an environment that will attract patients with comical diseases and then treat them while tending to their needs. The game has a somewhat [[black comedy|dark sense of humour]], similar to that of its predecessor, ''Theme Park''. Diseases include Bloaty Head (which swells the patient's head), King Complex (which forces the patient to impersonate [[Elvis Presley]]), and Alien DNA (which transforms the patient into an alien). Starting with an empty hospital,{{cite web|title=東京レトロゲームショウ2015：第12回 「テーマホスピタル」で人間のドラマがあちこちで繰り広げられる病院経営に挑みたい|url=http://www.4gamer.net/games/301/G030139/20150729045/|website=4Gamer.net|accessdate=6 October 2016|language=Japanese|date=30 July 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009121745/http://www.4gamer.net/games/301/G030139/20150729045/|archive-date=9 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} the player must build rooms and hire [[medical doctor|doctors]], [[nurse]]s, [[Janitor|handymen]] and [[receptionist]]s.Quick PlayGuide, pp. 9–11. Each staff member has statistics that affect their performance, and doctors can be trained so their statistics will increase.Manual, pp. 11,27,28. Rooms include GP's Offices, Psychiatric rooms, Operating Theatres and Pharmacies,Manual, pp. 7–11. and are built by placing down a blueprint, assigning the location of doors and windows, and then placing down required and optional pieces of furniture.Manual, p. 7. The player may also set up items such as benches, fire extinguishers, and plants in the open corridor spaces provided.Manual, pp. 11–13. The player is given time to build the hospital at the start of each level before patients start coming.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[PC Zone]]|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|issue=50|date=May 1997|page=7|ISSN=0967-8220|title=Theme Hospital|url=https://archive.org/details/PC_Zone_Issue_050_1997-05_Dennis_Publishing_GB|accessdate=6 October 2016|location=London}}Quick PlayGuide, p. 9. Patients see a GP in his office who either provides a diagnosis or sends them for further evaluation in a specialised diagnosis room. Once a diagnosis is made, the patient will be sent for treatment. While a few rooms are available at the start of the game, the rest must be researched.Manual, p. 10. Some rooms, such as the Inflator room—where patients with Bloaty Head are treated—contain machines which require regular maintenance by a handyman: if neglected for too long, they will explode, killing all occupants of the room.Manual, pp. 32,33. Doctors must have acquired certain specialist skills to practise in certain rooms, such as the Research room (used to research new rooms and cures, and improve existing ones) and Operating Theatre.Manual, pp. 8–11. There are rooms that only staff use, such as the Staff Room and the Training room, while patients also require certain rooms such as toilet facilities.Manual, pp. 10,11. Diagnosis and treatment cost patients money, and the player can change hospital policy, including the amount of diagnosis patients require. This can be set to over 100 per cent to force patients to have further unnecessary diagnoses. Other policies include when staff can go on breaks and whether they can leave rooms,Manual, pp. 23,24. and loans can be taken out.Manual, pp. 24,25. From time to time, events such as emergencies (in which patients arrive and must be cured within a time limit or they will die), and epidemics (in which a disease spreads rapidly) occur. During the latter, the player can attempt to cover it up by curing all affected patients before a health inspector turns up. If the player fails, he or she is fined and must face a damaged reputation,Manual, pp. 34,35. a statistic that shows how well the hospital is doing and affects the flow of patients.Manual, p. 5. VIPs may also occasionally ask to tour the hospital; if impressed, the player is granted a cash bonus, a reputation increase, or both.Manual, pp. 35,36. There is an advisor who keeps the player informed about what is going on.Manual, p. 4. Rats may infest the hospital, and the player is able to shoot them with the cursor.{{cite magazine|magazine=PC Zone|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|issue=52|date=July 1997|title=Everything you wanted to know about Theme Hospital but were too afraid to ask...|pages=126, 127|ISSN=0967-8220|location=London}} Although the player has no direct control over the patients, they have some influence over whether to evict them from the hospital and in determining what to do with them when given a choice by the staff. The player can pick up any staff member in the building and move them (mainly to reassign them to another room or send them to get rest), or dismiss them if they argue about pay or are no longer required.Manual, pp. 25–30. The player may force patients to take a chance at a cure for their suspected disease before diagnosis is complete (at the risk of killing the patient),Manual, p. 31. and rearrange queues.Manual, pp. 25,26. The player competes against computer rivals named after famous computers, real and fictional: these include [[Holly (Red Dwarf)|Holly]] from ''[[Red Dwarf (TV series)|Red Dwarf]]'' and [[Deep Thought (The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy)|Deep Thought]] from ''[[The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy]]''.{{cite web|author1=Mark Langshaw|title=Theme Hospital retrospective: Just what the doctor ordered|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/retro-corner/feature/a623869/theme-hospital-retrospective-just-what-the-doctor-ordered/|website=Digital Spy|accessdate=6 October 2016|date=24 January 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006175554/http://www.digitalspy.com/gaming/retro-corner/feature/a623869/theme-hospital-retrospective-just-what-the-doctor-ordered/|archive-date=6 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The game is timed with days of the year, and at the end of each year (game time), players are judged on their performances, and may be given trophies, reputation increases, or cash bonuses.Manual, pp. 37,38. Each level has set goals in the fields of financial attainment, hospital reputation, patients cured, and hospital value. Holding negative funds or allowing sufficient patients to die will bring about losing requirements. When the goals have been met the player has the option to move on to a new, more elaborate hospital with tougher winning conditions and more diseases present, or stick with their current one.Manual, p. 38. If enough rats have been shot, the player is taken to a special level whose goal is to shoot as many as possible. A [[Patch (computing)|patch]] was released that fixed bugs and added support for Serial Cable, Modem, and [[IPX/SPX]] network gaming (with up to four players{{cite web|title=EA's Darklight Conflict and Theme Hospital|url=http://www.gamezilla.com/reviews/previews/ea_preview.asp|website=Gamezilla|accessdate=6 October 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19990225072027/http://www.gamezilla.com/reviews/previews/ea_preview.asp|archivedate=25 February 1999|date=24 February 1999}}) in the Windows version, and a difficulty setting.{{cite av media notes|title=Theme Hospital Netplay|year=1997|author=Bullfrog}}{{cite av media notes|title=Theme Hospital ReadMe.txt|year=1997|author=Bullfrog}} In multiplayer, each player has a colour, which patients will wear to distinguish from those of other players. "Litter Bombs" are featured, allowing players to spread litter around other players' hospitals, while staff members can be persuaded to work for other players, and there are "Mini Missions", with instructions for players to perform. Players are also able to chat with each other during a game. == Development == ''Theme Hospital'' took over two years to develop.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Retro Gamer]]|publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]]|location=Bournemouth|ISSN=1742-3155|title=Revisiting Bullfrog: 25 Years On|pages=60–67|issue=110|date=December 2012}} The idea came from [[Peter Molyneux]] and journalist James Leach, who explored the possibility of other ''Theme'' games while discussing ''[[Theme Park (video game)|Theme Park]]''. Leach suggested a hospital, and Molyneux was enthusiastic about the idea. Development began when the designer [[Mark Webley]] selected ''Theme Hospital'' from a list of possible games put together by Molyneux, and Webley, along with the artist [[Gary Carr (video game developer)|Gary Carr]], visited the [[Royal Surrey County Hospital]], [[Great Ormond Street Hospital]], and [[Frimley Park Hospital]] for research and inspiration.{{cite web|title=Theme Hospital Behind The Scenes - DVD Extras|url=https://forum.gamestm.co.uk/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=17641|website=[[GamesTM]]|accessdate=6 January 2018|date=8 September 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180106173202/https://forum.gamestm.co.uk/viewtopic.php?f=2&t=17641|archive-date=6 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} Carr was initially displeased at the prospect of working on ''Theme Hospital'': he had previously left Bullfrog to work for [[The Bitmap Brothers]] because he did not have faith in ''Theme Park''. He chose to return based on his belief that he would work on ''[[Dungeon Keeper]]'', which he was eager to do. Initially, ''Theme Hospital'' was to feature real diseases, but these were replaced with fictional, comedic afflictions as it was decided that the game's maladies should not be too realistic: the team were faced with the dilemma of having to make the hospital fun and interesting, as Webley stated that theme parks are "colourful" compared to hospitals, and Carr believed that hospital rooms looked very similar and that it was hard to tell what each machine does.{{cite web|author1=Julian Benson|title=How the makers of Theme Hospital made hospital wards and diseases funny|url=https://www.pcgamesn.com/theme-hospital/theme-hospital-peter-molyneux-making-of|website=PCGamesN|accessdate=23 July 2017|date=29 June 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170731233711/https://www.pcgamesn.com/theme-hospital/theme-hospital-peter-molyneux-making-of|archive-date=31 July 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} It was during a hospital visit (after witnessing an operation that they were ordered out of because they were distracting the surgeon) that they came up with the idea of using made-up illnesses and cures: Carr considered death "quite sad" and believed that illness was not a popular subject. He stated that using made-up illnesses gave them "creative freedom", which he believed was essential. Webley said that Carr was concerned that using real diseases might be considered distasteful.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[GamesTM]]|issue=113|date=September 2011|pages=128–131|title=Behind The Scenes Theme Hospital|ISSN=1478-5889}} According to Carr, the team were aiming for humour rather than gore.{{cite magazine|magazine=Bullfrog Bulletin|publisher=Bullfrog Productions|title=Trying Your Patients...|pages=8, 9|issue=2|date=1995|location=Guildford}} During the initial stages of programming, Bullfrog hired James Leach, who wrote the game's text and came up with the diseases. Molyneux was not directly involved in the game's production as he was then working on ''Dungeon Keeper''.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Retro Gamer]]|publisher=[[Imagine Publishing]]|location=Bournemouth|ISSN=1742-3155|title=The Making of Theme Hospital|pages=46–51|issue=130|date=June 2014}} The graphic design was decided to be modelled from those of cartoons, and a goal was to have two thousand character animations.{{cite magazine|magazine=Bullfrog Bulletin|publisher=Bullfrog Productions|issue=3|date=1996|title=Hospital Update|page=11|location=Guildford}} Another artist was hired to complete the graphics on time, and the team ultimately ended up with four.Manual, p. 39. Fellow artist Andy Bass had difficulty getting the [[Kit-Kat]] graphics correct. He said they did not have the right colour, so Carr tweaked the palette. Bass modelled the vending machine that would use the Kit-Kat graphics and used [[Autodesk 3ds Max|3D Studio]] to render it into the game palette, which he then edited using [[Deluxe Paint]]. By spring 1996, around half of the illnesses and animations were complete, the introduction and [[cutscene]]s were mostly complete, and the programming of the management system was almost finished. By early 1997, all that was left was refining the difficulty levels. The game deviates from the [[National Health Service|NHS]] model; Webley and Carr decided that players should think of the hospital as a business, with profit highly important. The team, who worked in offices near the Royal Surrey County Hospital, drew some inspirations from ''Theme Park'' and borrowed a great deal of code. Webley explained that this was an "obvious starting point" as he had been a programmer on ''Theme Park'', and that the systems had been rewritten by the time ''Theme Hospital'' was complete. A program which facilitated animation was built upon by Webley, who dubbed it the Complex Engine. There were not many meetings, and Webley took the team to the pub weekly with a list of tasks to perform. Webley explained that the way the team worked meant that only they could perform their assigned duties otherwise they would not get done, effectively giving members ownership of their parts of the game. It was during one such meeting that the team realised the game was complete. The disease called King Complex was to be called Elvis Impersonator, but Elvis's estate owned the rights. Bloaty Head was based on an allergic reaction Molyneux had, when his face became an "alarming size". According to Leach, the volume of work was small. A big problem was that the team had too many ideas, and insufficient time to implement them all. For example, other diseases were planned; one of these was Animal Magnetism, which would see patients with attached animals which would have to be cut away. Another idea that was not implemented was the possibility of four separate in-game eras: futuristic, mediaeval, Victorian, and modern.{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=Theme Hospital|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=14 |publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=February 1996|page=91|quote=To start, players choose between one of four different time periods, the Middle Ages, the Victorian Era, 1970s-1980s, and of course, the future.|ISSN=1078-9693}} The game was originally to have players begin in the mediaeval zone, and progress to more modern ones. By May 1996, the idea of the other time periods had been deemed "prohibitive" due to the amount of graphics required.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[PC Zone]]|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|issue=38|date=May 1996|pages=33, 34|ISSN=0967-8220|title=Theme Hospital|location=London|department=Blueprint}} Carr later stated that the game did not need the other eras, and that the team was small enough to make things up as they went along. Carr was also afraid that if they had produced a design document, Electronic Arts would have considered the omission of the other eras feature cutting. An idea that Molyneux pushed Webley's team to implement was a screen that enabled players to mix coloured chemicals to apply them to diseases. Accessibility was also a concern for the team: with so many options, it was felt that players could treat the game like work. The tester Jon Rennie simplified the game from the original design; Webley was keen for players to be able to begin play without a long tutorial. ''Theme Hospital'' was released in March 1997 (although it was previously due for release in November 1996{{cite magazine|magazine=Edge|publisher=[[Future plc]]|issue=36|date=September 1996|page=36|ISSN=1350-1593|title=Theme Hospital|department=Prescreen|location=Bath}}),{{cite magazine|magazine=Bullfrog Bulletin|publisher=Bullfrog Productions|issue=4|date=1997|title=Theme Hospital|pages=4–6|location=Guildford}} and is part of Bullfrog's ''Designer Series''.{{cite video game|title=Theme Hospital|developer=Bullfrog|publisher=Electronic Arts|date=1997|platform=PC|scene=Intro}}{{cite magazine|magazine=Edge|publisher=[[Future plc]]|issue=22|date=July 1995|pages=25–27|ISSN=1350-1593|title=Bullfrog|location=Bath}} The game attracted some controversy from NHS managers, the [[Houses of Parliament]], and ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'', who published an article criticising the game as "sick" and said that the [[British Medical Association]] was using it to train management staff. The NHS argued that the game mocked hospital management. Webley was invited to appear on a local radio station; he did not consider the game to make light of real-world health management because it featured fictional diseases rather than real ones. ''Theme Hospital'' was a commercial success, which surprised Bullfrog and Electronic Arts. It repeatedly appeared in the top five of budget charts and sold over 4 million copies. In 2014, Molyneux stated that he wanted the game to make a comeback, and described ''Theme Hospital'' as "a great game that I and many people remember". Original releases' cover art used a green cross on a white background, which Bullfrog did not have the right to use. The artwork was mistakenly approved because it was faxed in black and white, and had to be recalled. Later releases changed the cross to a star. Despite its rejection, the cross version is available in more recent formats. === Sound === The music and sound effects were produced by [[Russell Shaw (composer)|Russell Shaw]] and Adrian Moore. Moore used [[Sound Forge]] to develop the sound effects. Some (such as the snooker balls) were taken directly from its library, and others (including the treatment machines) were created by mixing sounds together. Some machine sounds were created by mixing the sounds of electric egg mixer with that of a hydraulic lifter. The farting sounds were recorded when Moore was working with bands including [[T'Pau (band)|T'Pau]], [[Prefab Sprout]], and [[Seal (band)|Seal]] at a recording studio: he did so as a joke, but they were useful for ''Theme Hospital''. === Ports and re-releases === A [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] port of ''Theme Hospital'' was developed by [[Krisalis Software]] and released by Electronic Arts in 1998.{{cite web|title=Theme Hospital [PS]|url=http://gamestopplus.com/game.php?title=theme-hospital&genre=strategy&platform=ps|website=GameStopPlus|accessdate=5 October 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006154112/http://gamestopplus.com/game.php?title=theme-hospital&genre=strategy&platform=ps|archive-date=6 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} The PlayStation version was released as a download on the [[PlayStation 3]] and [[PlayStation Portable]] from [[PlayStation Store]] in Europe on 31 January 2008,{{cite web|author1=Tom Branwell|title=More PSone games on PSN|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/more-psone-games-on-psn|website=Eurogamer|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=31 January 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006155612/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/more-psone-games-on-psn|archive-date=6 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} in North America on 31 August 2010,{{cite web|title=Theme Hospital (PSOne Classic)|url=https://store.playstation.com/#!/en-ca/games/theme-hospital-(psone-classic)/cid=UP9000-NPUJ00275_00-0000000000000001|website=PlayStation Store|publisher=Sony|accessdate=5 October 2016|archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6hLz2LwKJ?url=https://store.playstation.com/#!/en-ca/games/theme-hospital-(psone-classic)/cid=UP9000-NPUJ00275_00-0000000000000001|archive-date=8 May 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and in Japan on 28 October 2009.{{cite web|title=テーマホスピタル|trans-title=Theme Hospital|url=http://www.jp.playstation.com/software/title/jp0006npjj00299_000000000000000001.html|website=PlayStation.com|publisher=Sony|accessdate=6 October 2016|language=Japanese|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009213947/http://www.jp.playstation.com/software/title/jp0006npjj00299_000000000000000001.html|archive-date=9 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} This version is no longer available for purchase in Europe since September 2014, after becoming free for a short period of time.{{cite web|author1=Meg Pelliccio|title=Theme Hospital free on EU PSN|url=https://www.pixeldynamo.com/news/gaming/2014/09/11/29006/theme-hospital-free-eu-psn/|website=Pixel Dynamo|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=11 September 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009101644/https://www.pixeldynamo.com/news/gaming/2014/09/11/29006/theme-hospital-free-eu-psn/|archivedate=9 October 2016|df=dmy-all}} A [[Sega Saturn]] version (titled ''Sim Hospital'' as of October 1995) was in development and due for release in mid-1996, but was cancelled.{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=Killer Bullfrogs Launch Game|magazine=Mean Machines Sega|issue=36 |publisher=[[Emap International Limited]]|date=October 1995|pages=13|issn=0967-9014|location=Peterborough|department=News|url=https://archive.org/details/mean-machines-sega-magazine-36|accessdate=21 October 2016}} In 2012, ''Theme Hospital'' was re-released on the [[Digital distribution|digital distribution service]] [[GOG.com]].{{cite web | url = http://gameranx.com/features/id/6201/article/theme-hospital-in-hd-is-glorious-here-s-how-to-get-it-working/ | title = Theme Hospital in HD is Glorious! Here's How To Get It Working | date = 16 April 2012 | website = Gameranx | publisher = [[Complex (magazine)|Complex]] | first = Dave | last = Oshry | access-date = 12 May 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160506154248/http://gameranx.com/features/id/6201/article/theme-hospital-in-hd-is-glorious-here-s-how-to-get-it-working | archive-date = 6 May 2016 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }} In January 2015, [[Origin (digital distribution software)|Origin]] distributed ''Theme Hospital'' free for a limited time through their "On the House" programme.{{cite web | url = http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-01-21-theme-hospital-is-free-to-download-on-origin | title = Theme Hospital is free to download on Origin | website = [[Eurogamer]] | date = 21 January 2015 | first = Tom | last = Phillips | access-date = 12 May 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160510185729/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2015-01-21-theme-hospital-is-free-to-download-on-origin | archive-date = 10 May 2016 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }} It was distributed a second time through the "On the House" programme in September 2015, as a temporary replacement to ''[[Command & Conquer: Red Alert 2]]'' due to an [[Artificial scarcity|excessive]] number of requests for the latter.{{cite web | url = http://www.dealspwn.com/theme-hospital-on-the-house-red-alert-2-225650 | title = Theme Hospital is once again On The House, Red Alert 2 to return "very shortly" | date = 17 September 2015 | first = Carl | last = Phillips | website = Dealspwn | access-date = 12 May 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160426050813/http://www.dealspwn.com/theme-hospital-on-the-house-red-alert-2-225650 | archive-date = 26 April 2016 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }} It was released a third time in selected countries from 7 March 2017 until 17 May 2017 as a replacement for ''[[Syberia 2]]''.{{cite web|url=https://www.neowin.net/news/theme-hospital-and-siberia-ii-offered-for-free-on-ea-origin-for-a-limited-time|title=Theme Hospital and Syberia II offered for free on EA Origin for a limited time|website=Neowin|last=Chan|first=Boyd|date=8 March 2017|access-date=17 May 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170324102646/https://www.neowin.net/news/theme-hospital-and-siberia-ii-offered-for-free-on-ea-origin-for-a-limited-time|archive-date=24 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} An [[Open-source video game|open-source]] [[Video game remake|remake]], ''CorsixTH'', improves the game with features such as higher screen resolutions and a level editor.{{cite web|author1=Moritz Förster|title=CorsixTH: Bullfrogs Theme Hospital auf aktuellen Rechnern spielen|url=http://www.heise.de/newsticker/meldung/CorsixTH-Bullfrogs-Theme-Hospital-auf-aktuellen-Rechnern-spielen-3237075.html|website=heise online|trans-title=CorsixTH: Bullfrogs Theme Hospital on 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ''CorsixTH'' is available under the [[MIT Licence]],{{cite web|author1=James Gilmour|title=Free version of Theme Hospital available on Android|url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/Android/CorsixTH/news.asp?c=41208|website=Pocket Gamer|accessdate=17 October 2016|date=22 May 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161018210706/http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/Android/CorsixTH/news.asp?c=41208|archive-date=18 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} and in 2012, a version was released on [[Android (operating system)|Android]], available on the [[Google Play]] Store.{{cite web | first = Alan | last = Woolley | date = 22 February 2012 | title = Running Theme Hospital on Android with CorsixTH | url = http://www.armedpineapple.co.uk/2012/02/running-theme-hospital-on-android-with-corsixth/ | website = Armed Pineapple | access-date = 12 May 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160420025044/https://www.armedpineapple.co.uk/2012/02/running-theme-hospital-on-android-with-corsixth/ | archive-date = 20 April 2016 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }}{{cite web | first = Alan | last = Woolley | url = https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=uk.co.armedpineapple.cth | title = CorsixTH | website = [[Google Play Store]] | access-date = 12 May 2016 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160501061220/https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=uk.co.armedpineapple.cth | archive-date = 1 May 2016 | dead-url = no | df = dmy-all }} == Reception == {{Video game reviews |CVG = {{Rating|4|5}} (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=Computer and Video Games|publisher=[[EMAP]]|issue=186|date=May 1997|pages=74, 75|title=Theme Hospital|ISSN=0261-3697|last=Huhtala|first=Alex|location=Peterborough}} |PCGUK = 85% (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=[[PC Gamer]]|last=Owen|first=Steve|title=Theme Hospital|date=April 1997|pages=86, 87|publisher=[[Future plc]]|ISSN=1470-1693|issue=42|location=Bath}} |GSpot = 5.5/10 (PC){{cite web|author1=Trent Ward|title=Theme Hospital Review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/theme-hospital-review/1900-2533405/|website=GameSpot|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=17 April 1997|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161004181009/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/theme-hospital-review/1900-2533405/|archive-date=4 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}}
7.3/10 (PlayStation){{cite web|author1=James Mielke|title=Theme Hospital Review|url=http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/theme-hospital-review/1900-2549740/|website=GameSpot|publisher=GameSpot|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=18 May 1998|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161004172657/http://www.gamespot.com/reviews/theme-hospital-review/1900-2549740/|archive-date=4 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |IGN = 7/10 (PlayStation){{cite web|title=Theme Hospital|url=http://uk.ign.com/articles/1998/04/16/theme-hospital|website=IGN|publisher=IGN|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=15 April 1998}} |rev1 = ''Coming Soon Magazine'' |rev1Score = 82% (PC){{cite web|author1=Frederick Claude|title=Theme Hospital – PC Review|url=http://www.csoon.com/issue25/themehos.htm|website=Coming Soon Magazine|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=1997|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006040643/http://www.csoon.com/issue25/themehos.htm|archive-date=6 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |rev2 = [[EP Daily|The Electric Playground]] |rev2Score = 6.5/10 (PC){{cite web|author1=Bonnie James|title=Theme Hospital|url=http://www.elecplay.com/pc/themehospital.html|website=The Electric Playground|publisher=The Electric Playground|accessdate=5 October 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970801055330/http://www.elecplay.com/pc/themehospital.html|archivedate=1 August 1997|date=14 April 1997|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} |CGW = {{Rating|4|5}} (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=[[Computer Gaming World]]|publisher=[[Ziff Davis]]|ISSN=0744-6667|title=Rx for Fun|page=194|url=http://www.cgwmuseum.org/galleries/issues/cgw_157.pdf#page=198|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=August 1997|last=Jepsen|first=Dawn|issue=157|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923222346/http://www.cgwmuseum.org/galleries/issues/cgw_157.pdf#page=198|archive-date=23 September 2015|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |Edge =8/10 (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=Edge|publisher=[[Future plc]]|issue=44|date=April 1997|page=84|ISSN=1350-1593|title=Theme Hospital|department=Testscreen|location=Bath}}
7/10 (PlayStation){{cite magazine|magazine=Edge|publisher=[[Future plc]]|issue=56|date=March 1998|page=104|ISSN=1350-1593|title=Theme Hospital|department=Testscreen|location=Bath}} |rev3 = [[Eurogamer]] |rev3Score = 7/10 (PlayStation){{cite web|author1=Dan Whitehead|title=PSN Roundup|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/r_psnroundup_040208|website=Eurogamer|publisher=Eurogamer|accessdate=5 October 2016|date=4 February 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161006145329/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/r_psnroundup_040208|archive-date=6 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |rev4 = [[Jeuxvideo.com]] |rev4Score = 17/20 (PC){{cite web|title=Test : Theme Hospital|url=http://www.jeuxvideo.com/articles/0001/00011486-theme-hospital-test.htm|website=Jeuxvideo.com|accessdate=6 October 2016|language=French|date=19 September 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161009230431/http://www.jeuxvideo.com/articles/0001/00011486-theme-hospital-test.htm|archive-date=9 October 2016|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} |rev5=Absolute PlayStation |rev5Score=79% (PlayStation){{cite web|title=THEME HOSPITAL|url=http://www.absolute-playstation.com/api_review/rthemeh.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000528182426/http://absolute-playstation.com/api_review/rthemeh.htm|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2000-05-28|website=Absolute PlayStation|accessdate=6 October 2016|date=June 1998}} |rev6 = ''[[PC Zone]]'' |rev6Score=91% (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=[[PC Zone]]|publisher=[[Dennis Publishing]]|ISSN=0967-8220|pages=72–76|issue=49|date=April 1997|title=Theme Hospital|location=London}} |rev7 = ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]'' |rev7Score = {{rating|4|5}} (PC){{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=Theme Hospital|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]|issue=31|publisher=[[Imagine Media]] |date=July 1997|page=170|volume=3|ISSN=1078-9693}} |rev8 = ''PC Power'' |rev8Score = 92% (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=PC Power|publisher=Rapide Publishing|location=Newton Abbot|issue=40|date=April 1997|ISSN=1352-7894|title=Theme Hospital|pages=46, 47}} |rev9=''[[:fr:Gen4|Génération 4]]'' |rev9Score = {{rating|5|5}} (PC){{cite magazine|magazine=Génération 4|ISSN=1624-1088|title=Theme Hospital L'infâme en blanc|pages=106–112|date=March 1997|issue=97|language=French|author=Éric Ernaux}} }} ''Theme Hospital'' received positive reviews. Critics noted the strong gameplay, detailed graphics, satisfying comedic tone, and voice acting performance, but fell conflicted on music, repetition, the artificial intelligence, and the user interface. The British magazine ''[[PC Gamer]]''{{'s}} Steve Owen praised the game's challenge and "cute" graphics, but criticised the interface. Frederick Claude of ''Coming Soon Magazine'' also complimented the graphics as "highly detailed", and the "very simple" user interface, although he criticised the repetitiveness and lack of multiplayer support that would later be introduced with a patch. [[GameSpot]]{{'s}} Trent Ward agreed about the graphics too, lauding them as "fantastic", and also complimented the "realistic" voice acting performance, and the humour, although he criticised the [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|artificial intelligence]] as "flawed". His conclusion was that the game "just doesn't fly". Bonnie James of [[EP Daily|The Electric Playground]] also liked the graphics, as well as the "lovely" opening sequence, but found the music "horrible". ''[[Computer and Video Games]]''{{'s}} Alex Huhtala concurred about the graphics, describing them as "large and colourful", but commented that the humour wears off after a while, although he felt it is good to begin with. Another reviewer who liked the graphics was Dawn Jepsen of ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'', who also praised the humour, especially the "wackiness" of the illnesses, and described the game as "delightful and absorbing". The humour was also approved by a reviewer of [[Jeuxvideo.com]], who, like other reviewers, lauded the graphics, by describing them as colourful. ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]''{{'s}} reviewer echoed others' views about the humour, describing it as something they had come to except from Bullfrog, but criticised the lack of multiplayer support. The humour was again praised by a reviewer of ''PC Power'', who said that the ailments enabled Bullfrog to have "hilarious" cures. The "thoroughly engrossing" gameplay, and the graphics were also complimented: it was stated that the bright colours gave hospitals a "cheerful look". ''Theme Hospital'' was described as a "fantastic title". Other comments from critics included ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]''{{'s}} reviewer's compliments of the balance of patients and illnesses against the player's resources, and his belief that the game is a refinement of its genre, and ''[[PC Zone]]''{{'s}} reviewers commendation of the detail: it was remarked that it gets players "helplessly immersed", and the game was awarded the ''PC Zone'' Classic accolade. Éric Ernaux of ''[[:fr:Gen4|Génération 4]]'' said the quality is "remarkable for a game of its genre". The PlayStation version's main problem, as noted by critics, was the controls. It was cited by reviewers from GameSpot, [[IGN]], Eurogamer, and ''Edge'' as a major downside. Its reception was not entirely negative: James Mielke of GameSpot also commended the addictiveness, and described the port as "almost completely intact". IGN agreed with others about the humour, by praising it as "wonderfully sick". It was further commented that the game's "brilliance" made it a "must-have". The sentiments about the controls and humour were echoed by Dan Whitehead of [[Eurogamer]], who reviewed it on the PlayStation Network. Absolute PlayStation's reviewers had a mixed view about the graphics: they criticised the resolution and colour palette, but complimented the sprites. The user interface was criticised as being reminiscent of a [[Fourth generation of video game consoles|16-bit game]]. Despite the criticisms, they agreed with others about the humour, and described the game as "a blast to play". In 1997, ''Theme Hospital'' appeared alongside ''Theme Park'' at #61 on ''PC Gamer''{{'}}s list of top 100 games,{{cite magazine|title=The PC Gamer Top 100|issue=45|magazine=[[PC Gamer]]|date=July 1997|publisher=[[Future plc]]|issn=1470-1693|page=61|location=Bath}} and was named in April as a Game of Distinction. === Legacy === On 13 November 2017, Oxymoron Games revealed that they were working on ''Project Hospital'', which, according to [[Eurogamer]], is their take on ''Theme Hospital''.{{cite web|author1=Matt Wales|title=Project Hospital is a "fresh" indie take on Bullfrog's Theme Hospital, minus the Bloaty Head|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-11-13-project-hospital-is-a-fresh-indie-take-on-theme-hospital-minus-the-bloaty-head|website=[[Eurogamer]]|accessdate=16 January 2018|date=13 November 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180117131303/http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-11-13-project-hospital-is-a-fresh-indie-take-on-theme-hospital-minus-the-bloaty-head|archive-date=17 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} On 16 January 2018, [[Two Point Studios]], a studio founded by Webley and Carr, announced ''[[Two Point Hospital]]'', a [[spiritual sequel]] to ''Theme Hospital''.{{cite web|title=Theme Hospital creators announce Two Point Hospital|url=http://metro.co.uk/2018/01/16/theme-hospital-creators-announce-two-point-hospital-7234494/|website=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=16 January 2018|date=16 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180116191605/http://metro.co.uk/2018/01/16/theme-hospital-creators-announce-two-point-hospital-7234494/|archive-date=16 January 2018|dead-url=no|df=dmy-all}} ''Two Point Hospital'' was released on 30 August 2018,{{cite web |author1=GameCentral |title=Two Point Hospital review – healthy obsession |url=https://metro.co.uk/2018/08/31/two-point-hospital-review-healthy-obsession-7899066/ |website=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]] |accessdate=31 August 2018 |date=31 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180904224617/https://metro.co.uk/2018/08/31/two-point-hospital-review-healthy-obsession-7899066/ |archive-date=4 September 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} and ''Project Hospital'' is due for release on 30 October 2018.{{cite web |title=Project Hospital |url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/868360/Project_Hospital/ |website=Steam |accessdate=31 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831073727/https://store.steampowered.com/app/868360/Project_Hospital/ |archive-date=31 August 2018 |dead-url=no |df=dmy-all }} ''Two Point Hospital'' features the Animal Magnetism disease, that was originally cut from ''Theme Hospital'' before release.{{Cite web |title=Two Point Hospital review |last=Brown|first=Fraser|work=[[PC Gamer US]] |date= |access-date=8 September 2018 |url=https://www.pcgamer.com/two-point-hospital-review/ |quote=}} == See also == {{portal|Video games|1990s|United Kingdom}} * ''[[Hospital Tycoon]]'', a similar simulation game {{clear}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} === Sources === * {{cite book|title=Theme Hospital PC Manual|date=1997|publisher=Bullfrog|edition=UK}} * {{cite book|title=Theme Hospital PC Quick PlayGuide|date=1997|publisher=Bullfrog|edition=UK}} == External links == * {{MobyGames|/theme-hospital/}} {{Bullfrog Productions}} [[Category:1997 video games]] [[Category:Bullfrog Productions {{for|the board game the game is based on|Ticket to Ride (board game)}} {{Infobox video game |width= |title= Ticket to Ride |image= Tickettoride logo.jpg |caption= |developer= [[Next Level Games]] (XBLA),[http://www.xblah.net/2008/05/oflc-watch-ticket-to-ride-crazy-mouse.html OFLC Watch - Ticket To Ride, Crazy Mouse, and Darwinia+ rated] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080505221637/http://www.xblah.net/2008/05/oflc-watch-ticket-to-ride-crazy-mouse.html |date=2008-05-05 }} from XBLAH! [[Days of Wonder]] (PC, MAC & iOS) |publisher= [[Playful Entertainment, Inc.]] (XBLA), Days of Wonder (PC, MAC & iOS) |designer= |series= |engine= |released= June 25, 2008 (XBLA)
May 18, 2011 (iOS)
May 24, 2012 (PC, OS X)
October 15, 2013 (Linux, Android) |genre= [[Turn-based strategy]] |modes= [[Single-player video game|Single-player]], [[Multiplayer video game|multiplayer]] |platforms= [[Xbox 360]], [[Microsoft Windows]], [[iOS]], [[OS X]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Xbox One backwards compatibility]] }} '''''Ticket to Ride''''' is a [[turn-based strategy]] [[video game]], based upon [[Alan R. Moon]]'s [[German-style board game]] [[Ticket to Ride (board game)|of the same name]], developed by [[Next Level Games]] and published by Playful Entertainment, Inc. The title was released on June 25, 2008.[http://gamerscoreblog.com/team/archive/2008/06/23/559646.aspx Happy Tree Friends False Alarm and Ticket to Ride - This Week - XBLA] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080626073958/http://gamerscoreblog.com/team/archive/2008/06/23/559646.aspx |date=2008-06-26 }} from GamerScoreBlog.com In February 2017 Days of wonder abandoned Linux support.[https://steamcommunity.com/app/108200/discussions/0/133256959377980187/ Dropped Linux support] from steamcommunity.com == Gameplay == [[File:Tickettoride ss.jpg|left|thumb|Gameplay screenshot.]] Gameplay is identical to the board game: there are two types of cards, colored train cars representing a type of cargo (e.g., black represents [[Tender locomotive|coal cars]]), and destination cards which feature two city destinations (e.g., [[Chicago]] to [[Miami]]). Each player is dealt three destination cards, and must choose at least two of them. They are also dealt six train cards. Players may draw train cards, a new destination card, or claim a colored route on their turn. To claim a route, a player must pay with a combination of same-colored cards including [[locomotives]] which serve as wild cards. Once a route is claimed, no other player may claim it; some routes feature double routes which allow up to two players to claim it, but only if four or five players are playing. In two or three-player games, the double routes can only be claimed by one person. The players immediately earn points for each successful route they claim. At the end of the game, players earn the points listed on the destination card. If a player decides to pick a new destination card, he draws three cards and may choose any of the cards; however, the player ''must'' pick at least one destination. The game ends when at least one of the players has expended their trains. Players are given bonuses for completed destinations, and penalized for unrealized destinations. The player with the longest contiguous route earns an additional bonus. ===Multiplayer=== ''Ticket to Ride'' supports play with up to five people on [[Xbox Live]] or four people on the same console, and supports the [[Xbox Live Vision|Xbox Live Vision cam]].{{cite web| title= Ticket to Ride Headed to XBLA| url= http://gamerscoreblog.com/team/archive/2008/05/12/559073.aspx | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080517020846/http://gamerscoreblog.com/team/archive/2008/05/12/559073.aspx | archivedate= 2008-05-17| work= GamerScoreBlog| date= May 12, 2008}} It also supports [[Steam (software)|Steam]].{{cite web| url= http://www.daysofwonder.com/online/en/about/ | title= Days of Wonder online| publisher= daysofwonder.com | accessdate=2013-02-28| quote=Days of Wonder board games are distributed in 30 countries and their digital versions are available on iOS, as well as on Steam and Days of Wonder's web site.}} ==Downloadable content== The [[Ticket to Ride (board game)#Europe|Europe map]] was released for download on August 1, 2008 for Xbox Live Arcade and on May 24, 2012 on PC and Mac.{{cite web|url=http://majornelson.com/archive/2008/08/01/dlc-ticket-to-ride-europe.aspx|title=DLC: Ticket to Ride Europe|author=Larry Hryb|date=2008-08-01|accessdate=2008-07-01|work=[[Microsoft]]}} The Europe map includes two new types of route in addition to a new map: 'Ferry' routes, which require 'Locomotive' cards to be played when claiming them, and 'Tunnel' routes, which add an element of risk and chance to the game. The [[Ticket to Ride (board game)#USA 1910|1910 USA map]] was released on September 17, 2008 on Xbox Live Arcade and on May 24, 2012 for PC and Mac.{{cite web| url=http://gamerscoreblog.com/team/archive/2008/09/15/561095.aspx| title=Domino Master, Feeding Frenzy 2 and Content for Ticket to Ride Coming to XBLA on Wednesday!| date=2008-09-15| work=Gamerscore Blog| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080918105811/http://gamerscoreblog.com/team/archive/2008/09/15/561095.aspx| archivedate=2008-09-18| df=}} It added 35 new destination tickets, the Globetrotter bonus card (for completing the most routes), and a large map. The [[Ticket to Ride (board game)#Map Collection 1: Team Asia and Legendary Asia|Legendary Asia map]] from the Map Collection 1 expansion was released on August 2, 2012 for PC and Mac. The [[Ticket to Ride (board game)#Switzerland|Switzerland map]] was released on May 24, 2012 for PC and Mac. ==Reception== {{Video game reviews | GR = 69%[http://www.gamerankings.com/htmlpages2/946102.asp Ticket to Ride - X360] from Gamerankings | MC = 68%[http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/xbox360/tickettoride Ticket to Ride (xbox360: 2008): Reviews] from [[Metacritic]] | EuroG = 7/10 | IGN = 6.5/10 | OXM = 7/10 | TX = 7.9/10 }} {{Expand section|date=July 2008}} ==See also== *''[[Catan]]'' *[[Carcassonne (video game)|''Carcassonne'' (video game)]] *[[Lost Cities (video game)|''Lost Cities'' (video game)]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ticket To Ride (Video Game)}} [[Category:2008 video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Train simulation video games]] [[Category:Video games based on board games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Canada]] [[Category:Xbox 360 Live Arcade games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Steam Greenlight games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Linux games]] [[Category:Android (operating system) games]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Organizations established by the United Nations]]; added [[Category:United Nations organizations based in Asia]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox UN |name = United Nations University Institute on Computing and Society |ja name = |fr name = |zh name = 聯合國大學計算與社會研究所 |ru name = |es name = |ar name = |image = CSM-e1439285201707.jpg |image size = 200px |caption = The building of UNU-CS in Macau |type = University, Think Tank |acronyms = UNU-CS |head = |status = Active |resolution = |established = 2015 |ended = |headquarters = {{JPN}} [[Tokyo]] [[Shibuya]] |parent = |subsidiaries = |website = [http://cs.unu.edu/ cs.unu.edu] |commons = United Nations University Institute on Computing and Society (UNU-CS) |footnotes = }} [[File:UNU-CS logo.svg|thumb| UNU-CS logo]]
The '''United Nations University Institute on Computing and Society''' ('''UNU-CS'''; {{zh|c=聯合國大學計算與社會研究所}}) is an institute of the [[United Nations University|United Nations University (UNU)]], located in [[São Lázaro]], [[Macau]], [[China]]. Established in 2015, UNU-CS intends to assist the UN to achieve its agenda by working as a bridge between the UN and the international academic and public policy communities, training the next generation of interdisciplinary scientists in computing, social sciences and design for international development.<ref name="Ponto Final">{{cite news|language=pt|newspaper=Ponto Final | date=June 26, 2015|title=UNU-CS: a ONU em Macau, com novo projecto e novo director|author=John Pauleneses|url=https://pontofinalmacau.wordpress.com/2015/06/26/unu-cs-a-onu-em-macau-com-novo-projecto-e-novo-director/}}</ref>
UNU-CS succeeds the United Nations University International Institute for Software Technology (UNU-IIST), which was created by the United Nations University in Macau in 1991 following the agreement between the UN, the governments of Macao, Portugal and China. After the [[Transfer of sovereignty over Macau]], UNU-IIST lost some level of visibility.<ref name="Ponto Final"/> In 2015, the UNU-CS director Professor [[Michael L. Best]] was in charge of building the new succeeding institute “from scratch.”<ref name="Global Atlanta">{{cite news|newspaper=Global Atlanta|title=UN taps Georgia Tech Prof to launch Macau Program/|author=Phil Bolton|date=February 12, 2015|url=http://www.globalatlanta.com/article/27436/un-taps-georgia-tech-prof-to-launch-macau-program/|access-date=13 August 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150811200209/http://www.globalatlanta.com/article/27436/un-taps-georgia-tech-prof-to-launch-macau-program/|archive-date=11 August 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Goal== The goal of UNU-CS is "to nurture the next generation of computer and social scientists with the ability to participate in, shape and benefit from the rapid development of the global information society."<ref name="UNU-PR">{{cite press release |author=UNU|title= Prof. Michael Best Appointed Director of UNU Institute on Computing and Society, Macao, China|url=http://unu.edu/media-relations/releases/prof-michael-best-appointed-director-of-unu-institute-on-computing-and-society-macao-china.html |location= Macau|publisher= UNU|agency= UNU|date=2015-01-21 |access-date=2015-08-15}}</ref>
A research start-up, UNU-CS aims to do the following:<ref name="UNU-CS-about">{{cite web |url=http://cs.unu.edu/about/ |title=About |author=UNU-CS |year= 2015|website=UNU-CS Official Website |publisher= UNU-CS |access-date= 2015-08-16}}</ref> * Lead in investigating and inventing human centered information and communication technologies addressing some of the priorities central to the United Nations such as: sustainability, development, governance, peace and security, human rights and human dignity. * Impact policymakers, within the UN system and beyond, through actionable knowledge and thought-leadership. * Nurture the next generation of inter-disciplinary computing, information and social scientists; and engineers in developing countries. * Embrace the enormous dynamism of the city of Macau and Pearl River Delta region while still working globally.
According to its founding director, Professor Michael Best, his goal is "to raise the profile of the Institute as a centre of excellence in the UN system effectively responding to the needs of the developing world in this crucially important area.”<ref name="UNU-PR"/>
==Director== As of 2015, Professor Best directs the Technologies and International Development Lab as an associate professor at the Sam Nunn School of International Affairs and the School of Interactive Computing at Georgia Institute of Technology. He is also a co-founder and Editor-in-Chief Emeritus of the journal [[Information Technologies and International Development]] and a faculty associate of the Berkman Center for Internet and Society at Harvard University.<ref name="UNU-PR"/>
Professor Best leads the Global Computing column for [[Communications of the ACM]]. He holds a Ph.D. from MIT and has served as director of Media Lab Asia in India and head of the eDevelopment group at the [[MIT Media Lab]].<ref name="UNU-CS-about"/>
==Labs== Three "action-oriented research labs" are being developed:<ref name="UNU-CS-research-fellowship-cs">{{cite web |url=http://cs.unu.edu/join/research-fellowship-cs/ |title=Research Fellowship Opportunities: Peace, Data and Gender Lab |author=UNU-CS |year= 2015|website=UNU-CS Official Website |publisher= UNU-CS |access-date= 2015-08-16}}</ref> *Digital Peace Lab: ICTs for peacebuilding and to support human security, respond to crises, and mitigate human displacement. *Gender Tech Lab: ICTs that promote women’s empowerment and enable sustainable community led development. *Small Data Lab: ICTs that create actionable knowledge from local data, empower citizens with data they trust, and improve global datasets with local data.
==References== {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} * [http://cs.unu.edu United Nations University on Computing and Society] * [http://www.unu.edu United Nations University headquarters website]
