revision.comment: copy edit & cross linking
revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{RoughTranslation|French}} {{Underlinked|date= October 2014}} {{Refimprove|date= October 2014}} }} The '''VAE''' or '''Validation des Acquis de l'Expérience''' is a procedure that allows any [[France|French]] educational institution to grant [[academic degree|degree]]s partly or completely based on work experience. A portfolio of the applicant's achievements and work experience is presented to a committee at the educational institution. The committee will then decide if the documents presented in the portfolio show work that merits partial credit towards a particular degree.
== History ==
A French law, passed August 23, 1985, authorized people with work experience to ask for a Diploma equivalence. This was mostly for vocational degrees. A significant change came with the ''Loi de Modernisation Sociale'' (Law of Social Modernization) dated January 17, 2002, that specifically authorizes universities and other "''établissements d'Enseignemernt supérieurs''" ([[Education in France#Higher%20education|higher education institutions]]) to grant the standard degrees (''[[Brevet de technicien supérieur|BTS]], [[Diplôme d'études universitaires générales|DEUG]], [[Education in France#Higher education|Licence]], [[Education in France#Higher education|Maîtrise]], DES, [[Master of Advanced Studies#France and francophone countries|DESS]], Master, Mastaire, [[Doctorate#France|Doctorat]], etc.'') based only on the work experience of the candidate. The required minimum of work experience was also lowered from five to three years.
== Legal background ==
The VAE is now included in the French Code of Education ([http://legifrance.gouv.fr/WAspad/RechercheSimplePartieCode?commun=CEDUCA&code=CEDUCATL.rcv code l' Education de la République Française]) at Part legislative, Third part, Book VI, Title Ier, Chapter III, Section 2, Art. L613-3 to L613-6.
It is important to note that ([http://www.legifrance.gouv.fr/affichCodeArticle.do;jsessionid=E77F40F3FBBF70520B1B0471A95A37B6.tpdjo12v_1?idArticle=LEGIARTI000006525197&cidTexte=LEGITEXT000006071191&dateTexte=20140703&categorieLien=id&oldAction=&nbResultRech= Art L- 613-4]) states: "The validation produces the same effects as the knowledge or aptitude testing process that it replaces." The degrees and diplomas obtained through the VAE process are exactly the same and any mention of the VAE is prohibited in order to fight possible unlawful discrimination.
The VAE decision is done on file after interview (electronic or physical) by a VAE Jury made of professors belonging to the university.
== Recognition ==
At first, French professors and universities were reluctant to apply the VAE or were extremely difficult for the equivalences. {{Fact|reason=July 8, 2007|date=July 2007}} However the VAE is the law and all universities must apply it if asked. In 2005 21,379 applied for the VAE, 61% of them women. 59% received a full degree. Among those, 10% received a degree equivalent or superior to the bachelor degree.<ref>http://media.education.gouv.fr/file/18/1/3181.pdf</ref>
More than 1250 bachelor's or higher degrees were granted through the VAE in 2005 in France (+50%).
In France the VAE is, according to the government website, in full expansion and universally accepted. Internationally, the countries that ratified the [http://conventions.coe.int/Treaty/EN/Treaties/Html/165.htm Convention on the Recognition of Qualifications concerning Higher Education in the European Region] recognize it.
In the US, credentials evaluators, universities, federal and state governments also recognize the VAE degrees with the notable exception of the state of Oregon.{{Fact|date=July 2007}}
== Non-French speaking students ==
The VAE works like the European [[Erasmus Programme]] and the [[Bologna declaration|Bologna declaration on harmonization of European degrees]] that allows international students to attend French universities. In 2004 [[The Sorbonne]] started VAE in foreign languages ( English, Spanish & Italian) and was followed by several other universities. The validation documents provided to the committee at the university deciding the validation must be in a language that the committee members can read and understand if not in French.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ecotec.com/europeaninventory/publications/inventory/chapters/euro_inv_france.pdf A European inventory on validation of non-formal and informal learning - France], by Simon Roy (ECOTEC Research and Consulting), 2005. *[http://www.education.gouv.fr/cid1106/la-validation-des-acquis-de-l-experience-v.a.e.html French Ministry of Education VAE site] in French *[http://www.travail.gouv.fr/sous-dossiers.php3?id_rubrique=156&id_mot=307 French Ministry of Labour VAE site] in French *[http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/ewco/2004/04/FR0404NU04.htm VAE information] from [http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/ Eurofound].
[[Category:Education in France]]

revision.comment: fixed [[MOS:DASH|dashes]] using a [[User:GregU/dashes.js|script]]
revision.text:
'''Vladimir Anić''' (21 November 1930 – 30 November 2000) was a [[Croatia]]n [[linguistics|linguist]] and [[lexicography|lexicographer]]. He is best known as the [[author]] of ''Rječnik hrvatskoga jezika'' (1991), the first modern single-volume [[dictionary]] of [[Croatian language|Croatian]].
Anić was born in [[Užice]], [[Serbia]].<ref name="HE">{{citation |contribution-url=http://enciklopedija.hr/Natuknica.aspx?ID=2802 |contribution=Anić, Vladimir |title=[[Croatian Encyclopedia]] |year=1999–2009 |accessdate=January 1, 2014 |publisher=[[Leksikografski zavod Miroslav Krleža]] |language=Croatian}}</ref> He received a B.A. degree in Yugoslav languages and literature and Russian language and literature at the [[Faculty of Philosophy in Zagreb]] in 1956.<ref name=AnicBiogr>{{cite web |title=Vladimir Anić 1930. – 2000 |url=http://www.moljac.hr/biografije/anic.htm |language=Croatian |archivedate=2 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ANOiQ7RX?url=http://www.moljac.hr/biografije/anic.htm |accessdate=7 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> In 1963 he obtained a Ph.D. with the thesis ''Language of [[Ante Kovačić]]''.<ref name=AnicBiogr/> He taught at the Faculty of Philosophy in [[Zadar]] from 1960 to 1974, when he moved to the Faculty of Philosophy in Zagreb, becoming a full professor and head of the Department of Croatian literary language<ref>{{cite web |title=Katedra za hrvatski standardni jezik – bivši članovi Katedre |trans-title=Department of Croatian standard language – former members of the Department |url=http://www.ffzg.unizg.hr/kroat/index.php? |language=Croatian |publisher=''Kroatistika'' |location=Zagreb |archivedate=26 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6NgA1PyWP?url=http://www.ffzg.unizg.hr/kroat/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=276&Itemid=134 |accessdate=27 March 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> in 1976.<ref name=AnicBiogr/>
Anić published more than two hundred papers, studies, reviews and assays in subject areas of [[syntax]], [[phonology]], [[stress (linguistics)|accentuation]], [[morphology (linguistics)|morphology]], [[lexicography]], [[lexicology]], [[terminology]] and [[stylistics (linguistics)|stylistics]]. He taught at universities in Germany, Sweden and Slovenia. [[File:Rjecnik hrvatskoga jezika.jpg|thumb|right|Anić's Dictionary of Croatian language]] Vladimir Anić's most important and most widely known work is his dictionary of Croatian language. Started in 1972 and finally published in December 1991,<ref>{{cite news |first=Snježana |last=Kordić |authorlink=Snježana Kordić |date=9 December 1991 |title=Recenzija knjige Vladimira Anića, ''Rječnik hrvatskoga jezika'' |trans-title=Review of Vladimir Anić’s ''Croatian Dictionary'' |language=Croatian |location=Zagreb |publisher=''[[Vjesnik]]'' |issn=0350-3305 |page=9}}</ref> it appeared 90 years after the last comparable dictionary by [[Ivan Broz]] and [[Franjo Iveković]] was published in 1901. Two more significantly expanded and revised editions followed in 1994 and 1998,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Kordić, Snježana |authorlink=Snježana Kordić |title=Tragom uspjeha jednog rječnika: recenzija 3. izdanja knjige Vladimira Anića, ''Rječnik hrvatskoga jezika'' |trans-title=Tracking the success of a dictionary: Review of the 3rd edition of Vladimir Anić’s ''Croatian Dictionary'' |language=Croatian |journal=[[Kolo (magazine)|Kolo]] |location=Zagreb |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=490–492 |year=1998 |issn=1331-0992}}</ref> while the fourth edition, complete with a [[CD-ROM]] version,<ref>{{cite news |first=Neven |last=Jovanović |authorlink= |date=17 June 2004 |title=Mi bismo još!: Recenzija knjige Vladimira Anića, ''Veliki rječnik hrvatskoga jezika'' |trans-title=We want more!: Review of Vladimir Anić’s ''Big Croatian Dictionary'' |url=http://www.zarez.hr/132/rijeci2.htm |language=Croatian |location=Zagreb |publisher=''[[Zarez]]'' |archivedate=2 September 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ANOd2PLv?url=http://www.zarez.hr/132/rijeci2.htm |accessdate=2 March 2014 |df= }}</ref> was published posthumously in 2003.<ref>{{cite book|last=Anić |first=Vladimir |year=2003 |origyear=1st pub. 1991 |title=Veliki rječnik hrvatskoga jezika (4. izdanje) |trans-title=Big Croatian Dictionary (4th edition) |location=Zagreb |publisher=Novi Liber |page=1881 |isbn=953-6045-24-9}}</ref>
His two other major works are ''Pravopisni priručnik hrvatskoga jezika'' (first published as ''Pravopisni priručnik hrvatskoga ili srpskoga jezika'' in 1986), an [[orthography|orthographic]] manual coauthored with Josip Silić,<ref name=AnicBiogr/> and ''Rječnik stranih riječi'' (1999), a dictionary of [[loanword]]s in Croatian language, coauthored with [[Ivo Goldstein]].
As a linguist, Vladimir Anić was a staunch [[descriptivist]]; he saw his dictionary as "not a book of best words, but a book of all words", and stressed the need for language creativity and freedom<ref>{{cite journal |author=Kordić, Snježana |authorlink=Snježana Kordić |title=Protiv nasilja nad jezikom: recenzija knjige Vladimira Anića, ''Jezik i sloboda'' |trans-title=Against violence towards language: Review of Vladimir Anić’s ''Language and liberty'' |url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/446454.rec_ANIC_Jezik_i_sloboda_Rep.PDF |language=Croatian |journal=Republika |location=Zagreb |volume=55 |issue=5–6 |pages=246–251 |year=1999 |issn=0350-1337 |id={{ZDB|400820-0}} |archivedate=2 September 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ANNgcdgO?url=http://bib.irb.hr/datoteka/446454.rec_ANIC_Jezik_i_sloboda_Rep.PDF |accessdate=9 May 2015 |df= }}</ref> as a counterweight against [[language purism|purism]].<ref>{{cite web |last=Jergović |first=Miljenko |authorlink=Miljenko Jergović |date=4 March 2000 |title=Govorite li idiotski?: razgovor s Vladimirom Anićem |trans-title=Do you speak idiotic?: Interview with Vladimir Anić |url=http://postjugo.filg.uj.edu.pl/baza/texts_display.php?id=37 |language=Croatian |publisher=''[[Feral Tribune]]'' |archivedate=2 September 2012 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ANOX9E5F?url=http://postjugo.filg.uj.edu.pl/baza/texts_display.php?id=37 |accessdate=5 October 2013 |df= }}</ref>
He died in [[Zagreb]].<ref name="HE"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *{{worldcat id|id=lccn-nr87000283}} *{{OL author}} *{{LCAuth|nr87000283|Vladimir Anić||}} *[http://hjp.novi-liber.hr ''Hrvatski jezični portal''] – online Croatian dictionary based on Anić's work
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Anic, Vladimir}} [[Category:1930 births]] [[Category:2000 deaths]] [[Category:Linguists from Croatia]] [[Category:Croatian lexicographers]] [[Category:Linguistics educators]] [[Category:Faculty of Humanities and Social Sciences, University of Zagreb alumni]] [[Category:University of Zagreb faculty]] [[Category:Linguistics writers]] [[Category:20th-century linguists]] [[Category:Burials at Mirogoj Cemetery]]

revision.comment: /* Expertise reversal effect */
revision.text:
The '''worked-example effect''' is a learning effect predicted by [[cognitive load|cognitive load theory]] (Sweller, 1988). Specifically, it refers to the learning effect observed when worked-examples are used as part of instruction, compared to other instructional techniques such as problem-solving (Renkl, 2005) and discovery learning (Mayer, 2004). According to Sweller: "The worked example effect is the best known and most widely studied of the cognitive load effects" (Sweller, 2006, p. 165).
Worked-examples improve learning by reducing cognitive load during skill acquisition, and "is one of the earliest and probably the best known cognitive load reducing technique" (Paas et al., 2003). In particular, worked-examples provide instructions to reduce [[Cognitive load#Intrinsic|intrinsic cognitive load]] for the learner initially when few [[Schema (psychology)|schemas]] are available. [[Cognitive load#Extraneous|Extraneous load]] is reduced by scaffolding of worked-examples at the beginning of skill acquisition. Finally, worked-examples can increase [[Cognitive load#Germane|germane load]] when prompts for [[Worked-example effect#Self-explanations|self-explanations]] are used (Paas et al., 2003).
Renkl (2005) suggests that worked-examples are best used in "sequences of [[Worked-example effect#Faded worked examples|faded examples]] for certain problem types in order to foster understanding in skill acquisition," and that prompts, help system, and/or training be used to facilitate the learners' self-explanations. This view is supported by experimental findings comparing a faded worked-example procedure and a well-supported problem solving approach (Schwonke et al., 2009).
"However, it is important to note that studying [worked-examples] loses its effectiveness with increasing expertise" (Renkl, 2005), an effect known as the [[expertise reversal effect]] (Kalyuga, 2007). Further limitations of the classical worked-example method include "focusing on one single correct solution and on algorithmic skill domains" (Renkl, 2005). Addressing such restrictions in multimedia learning environments remains an area of active research (Renkl, 2005).
==Definitions==
===Worked example=== "A '''worked example''' is a step-by-step demonstration of how to perform a task or how to solve a problem" (Clark, Nguyen, Sweller, 2006, p. 190). Worked-examples are designed to support initial acquisition of cognitive skills through introducing a formulated problem, solution steps and the final solution (Renkl, 2005). Studying worked-examples is an effective instructional strategy to teach complex problem-solving skills (van Merriënboer, 1997). This is because example-based instruction provides expert mental models, to explain the steps of a solution for novices.
[[File:Worked Example.jpg|framed|center|A geometry worked-example using the tangent-radius property.]]
Worked examples, like the example above, are commonly found in mathematics or geometry textbooks, but they are also used in other fields. Worked-examples had been developed for music, chess, athletics, and computer programming (Atkinson, Derry, Renkl, & Wortham, 2000).
===Faded worked examples=== {{See also|Expertise reversal effect#Addressing|l1=Addressing Expertise Reversal Effect}}
"In order to facilitate the transition from learning from worked examples in earlier stages of skill acquisition to problem solving in later stages, it is effective to successively fade out worked solution steps" (Renkl et al., 2004). Fading out steps in worked-example triggers self-explanation activities, which consists of the learners' own explanations to the reasons for the given solution steps (Renkl et al., 2004).
As learners gain expertise in the subject area of interest, worked-examples lose their effectiveness due to the expertise reversal effect. Using fade worked-examples addresses this effect by structuring the learners' transition from studying worked-example to learning with problem-solving. (Salden et al., 2008)
===Self-explanations=== According to Renkl (2005), self-explanations are "explanations provided by learners and mainly directed to themselves. They contain information that is not directly given in the learning materials and that refer to solution steps and the reasons for them. They can also refer to structural and surface features of problems or problem types."
"Self-explanations are important and necessary" (Chi et al., 1989) when working with worked-example as "successful learners studied the examples for longer periods and explained them more actively to themselves" (Chi et al., 1989). However, as most learners are passive and superficial self-explainers (Renkl, 1997), they "should be guided to actively self-explain worked-out examples" (Renkl, 2005).
==Evidence for== The worked-example effect suggests that learning by studying worked examples is more effective than problem solving, and a number of research studies have demonstrated this effect.
Sweller and Cooper were not the first to use this form of instruction, but certainly they were the first to describe it from a [[cognitive load]] perspective (Sweller & Cooper, 1985; Cooper & Sweller, 1987; Sweller, 1988). While studying problem-solving tactics, Sweller and Cooper used worked examples as a substitute for conventional problem-solving for those learning algebra. They found that learners who studied worked examples, performed significantly better than learners who actively solved problems (Sweller & Cooper, 1985; Cooper & Sweller, 1987). Sweller and Cooper (1985) had developed worked examples as a means of limiting problem solving search. It is important to note, that Sweller & Cooper (1985) used worked-out example-problem pairs as opposed to individual worked examples. Renkl (2005) suggests learning from worked-out examples is more effective when a series is used. Pillay (1994) found that worked examples showing 3 intermediate problem stages were more effective than showing only one but suggested that the distance between stages needs to be small enough to allow students to connect them without having to create their own linkages.
Schwonke et al. (2009), in two experiments with Cognitive Tutors investigated the worked example effect. In one experiment, students used Geometry [[Cognitive Tutor]] which differed by the presentation of worked examples or not. In the experiment, students that were presented with worked examples needed less learning time to obtain the procedural skill and conceptual understanding of Geometry. In the second experiment, the authors aimed at avoiding the negative effects that occurred due to the lack of understanding of the purpose of worked examples, replicate the positive effects obtained in the first experiment and investigate the underlying learning approaches that explain why worked examples had greater efficiency effects. To achieve these objectives, the students were asked to think aloud, using the [[think aloud protocol]]. The results showed that the efficiency effect obtained in the first experiment was also replicated in the second experiment and the students had a deeper conceptual understanding (Schwonke et al., 2009).
Gog, Kester and Paas (2011) investigated the effectiveness of three strategies of example-based learning to problem solving on novices' cognitive load and learning; using electrical circuits troubleshooting tasks. The three strategies used are: worked example only, example-problem pairs and problem-example pairs. The results of the study showed that students in the worked example only and example-problems pair's conditions significantly outperformed students in the problem-example pair and problems solving conditions. It was also observed that higher performance was reached with significantly lower investment of mental efforts during the training (Gog, Kester and Paas, 2011).
===Expertise reversal effect=== Although a number of research studies have shown that worked-examples have positive effects on learners, Kalyuga et al. (2000, 2001a, b) showed that the worked-example effect is related to the expertise level of a learner, referred to as [[expertise reversal effect]]. In three studies, (Kalyuga et al. 2000, 2001a, b) used worked examples in different experiments, on-screen diagrams in mechanical engineering, examples with explanatory based instruction on writing circuits for relay circuits and programming logic. In the different studies, (Kalyuga et al. 2000, 2001a, b) showed that the efficiency effect of worked examples became ineffective and often resulted in negative effects for more knowledgeable learners (Kalyuga, 2007). However, Nievelstein et al. (2013) argues that both the worked-example effect and the expertise reversal effect that have been previously studied were based on well-structured cognitive tasks such as mechanics (Kalyuga et al. 2000). In a study using less-structured task, using legal cases, Nievelstein et al. (2013) investigates worked example effect and expertise reversal effects on both novice and advanced law students. The results of the study indicate that worked examples had efficiency effect for both the novice students and advanced law students, even though the advanced students had significantly more prior knowledge.
Another issue regarding worked examples was observed by Quilici & Mayer (1996), who found that providing learners with three examples of each problem type, as opposed to one, did not result in any differences in students' ability to sort subsequent problems into the appropriate types. As Wise & O'Neill, pointed out, this is not to say additional guidance will never lead to learning gains; we just cannot assume it always will.
There is also some debate as to how complete the worked example needs to be. Paas (1992) found that learners in a "completion" condition, who were given a problem only halfway worked out, performed just as well on test problems as those given the problems fully worked.
==Developing effective worked examples== Ward and Sweller (1990) suggested that under some conditions "worked examples are no more effective, and possibly less effective, than solving problems" (p. 1). Thus it is important that worked examples be structured effectively, so that extraneous cognitive load does not impact learners. Chandler and Sweller (1992) suggested an important way to structure worked examples. They found that the integration of text and diagrams (within worked examples) reduces [[extraneous cognitive load]]. They referred to this single modality, attention learning effect as the [[split-attention effect]] (Chandler and Sweller, 1992). Tabbers, Martens, & Van Merriënboer (2000) proposed that one may prevent split-attention by presenting text as audio.
Renkl (2005) suggests that students only gain deep understanding through worked-out examples when the examples: (1) are self-explanatory, (2) provide principle-based, minimalist, and example-relation instructional explanations as help (3) show relations between different representations (4) highlight structural features that are relevant for selecting the correct solution procedure (5) isolate meaningful building blocks.
Not all worked examples are print-based as those in the Tarmizi and Sweller study. [http://www.davidlewisphd.com/publications/dlewis_aect2005paper.pdf Lewis (2005)] for instance, proposed animated demonstrations are a form of worked example. Animated demonstrations are useful because this multimedia presentation combines the worked example, and modality effects within a single instructional strategy.
==Audience==
===Novice learners=== As it turns out, worked examples are not appropriate for all learners. Learners with prior knowledge of the subject find this form of instruction redundant, and may suffer the consequences of this redundancy. This has been described as the [[expertise reversal effect]] (Kalyuga, Ayres, Chandler, & Sweller, 2003). It is suggested that worked examples be faded over time to be replaced with problems for practice [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.23.6816&rep=rep1&type=pdf (Renkl, Atkinson & Maier, 2000)]. Thus it is important to consider the learner as well as the media while developing worked examples, else learners may not perform as expected.
Since worked-out examples include the steps toward reaching the solution; they can only be used in skill domains where algorithms can be applied (mathematics, physics, programming, etc.)(Renkl, 2005). For creative pursuits such as interpreting poems, or learning contexts when there is an infinite number of potential confounding factors such as conflict resolution, effective leadership, or multicultural communication, solution steps are more difficult to describe and worked-out examples may not be the most effective instructional method. Worked-out example approach is considered one of the best multimedia principles of learning mathematics. Worked examples helps to direct the learner's attention to what needs to be studied as well as developing literacy skills. It serves as a guide to preparing novice learners for effective problem solving after gaining an understanding of any concept under consideration. Renkl (2005) argues that learners have a very restricted understanding of the domain when they try to solve problems without any worked examples. Thus, learners gain deep understanding of a skill domain when they receive worked-out examples in the beginning of cognitive skill acquisition. The examples give learners a clue on the right steps to solving the problem.
A recent research (Rourke, 2006) found that novice learners can still have difficulty understanding concepts if the given examples with incomplete or somewhat inaccurate information (known as faded examples) prior to acquiring basic domain knowledge or literacy skills in the subject matter. This is based on how novice and expert learner structure his or her learning schemas - knowing the appropriate procedure/approach to use in retrieving and interpreting the problem. On the other hand, worked out examples may constitute cognitive load and causing redundancy to learners with prior knowledge (Kalyuga, Ayres, Chandler, & Sweller, 2003), in contrast with novice learners in which worked out examples rather serve as a compass that provides direct guides to solving similar problems (Rourke, 2006). This also apply when novice learners evaluate prototypes, which embody the main characteristics of a work, worked examples. This can also assist the novice learner with the semantic processing needed to fully comprehend a work of art or design (Rourke, 2006).
Worked examples model is one of several strong cognitive-instruction techniques with great importance that help teachers foster learning. It is an application principle that significantly enhances novice learners' patterns of knowledge acquisition in the contexts of authentic problem solving. Reed & Bolstad (1991) indicate that one example may be insufficient for helping a student induce a usable idea and that the incorporation of a second example illustrating the idea, especially one that is more complex than the first, garners significant benefits for transfer performance. So, "at least add a second example" appears to be a basic rule for worked-examples instructional design. In addition, Spiro, Feltovich, Jacobson, & Coulson (1991) affirmed that providing a wide range of examples (and having students emulate examples) that illustrate multiple strategies and approaches to similar problems help foster broad knowledge transfer and "cognitive flexibility".
The instructional model of example-based learning by Renkl and Atkinson (2007) suggests that students gain a deeper understanding of domain principles when they receive worked examples at the beginning of cognitive skill acquisition.
==See also== * [[Cognitive load]] * [[Example choice]] * [[Expertise reversal effect]] * [[Multimedia learning]] * [[Procedural memory]] * [[Split attention effect]] * [[Subgoal labeling]]

revision.text:
{{About|the knowledge of a language one has not learned| "speaking in tongues"|Glossolalia|the anime series|Idolmaster: Xenoglossia}} [[File:Charles Robert Richet 3.jpg|thumb|[[Charles Richet]] coined the term xenoglossy in 1905.]]
'''Xenoglossy''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|z|iː|n|ə|ˈ|ɡ|l|ɒ|s|i|,_|ˌ|z|ɛ|-|,_|-|n|oʊ|-}}<ref>Cf. analogously pronounced entry ''xenophobic'' in {{Citation |last=Jones |first=Daniel |author-link=Daniel Jones (phonetician) |title=English Pronouncing Dictionary |editors=Peter Roach, James Hartmann and Jane Setter |place=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |orig-year=1917 |year=2003 |isbn=3-12-539683-2 }}</ref>), also written '''xenoglossia''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|z|iː|n|ə|ˈ|ɡ|l|ɒ|s|i|ə|,_|ˌ|z|ɛ|-|,_|-|n|oʊ|-}}<ref>Cf. analogously pronounced entry ''xenophobia'' in {{Citation |last=Jones |first=Daniel |author-link=Daniel Jones (phonetician) |title=English Pronouncing Dictionary |editors=Peter Roach, James Hartmann and Jane Setter |place=Cambridge |publisher=Cambridge University Press |orig-year=1917 |year=2003 |isbn=3-12-539683-2 }}</ref><ref>{{Dictionary.com|xenoglossia}}</ref>), sometimes also known as '''xenolalia''', is the putative [[paranormal]] phenomenon in which a person is able to speak or write a language he or she could not have acquired by natural means. The words derive from [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ξένος (''xenos''), "foreigner" and γλῶσσα (''glōssa''), "tongue" or "language".<ref>[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.04.0057%3Aentry%3Dglw%3Dssa γλῶσσα], Henry George Liddell, Robert Scott, ''A Greek-English Lexicon'', on Perseus</ref> The term xenoglossy was ostensibly coined by French [[parapsychologist]] [[Charles Richet]] in 1905. Stories of xenoglossy are found in the Bible, and contemporary claims of xenoglossy have been made by parapsychologists and [[reincarnation]] researchers such as [[Ian Stevenson]]. There is no scientific evidence that xenoglossy is an actual phenomenon.<ref>Zusne, Leonard; Jones, Warren. (1989). ''Anomalistic Psychology: A Study of Magical Thinking''. Lawrence Erlbaum Associates. pp. 145-146. {{ISBN|978-0-805-80507-9}}</ref><ref name="www-personal.umich.edu">[[Sarah Thomason|Thomason, Sarah]]. "[http://www-personal.umich.edu/~thomason/papers/xenogl.pdf Xenoglossy"]. In [[Gordon Stein]]. (1996). ''The Encyclopedia of the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. {{ISBN|1-57392-021-5}}</ref><ref name=Gordon>{{citation|author=[[J. Gordon Melton|Melton, J. Gordon]]|title=The Encyclopedia of Religious Phenomena|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=n2LTTK5B_OMC&pg=PA359|date=1 January 2007|publisher=Visible Ink Press|isbn=978-1-57859-209-8|pages=359–|authormask=|format=|origyear=|oclc=|doi=|bibcode=|id=|quote=|laysummary=|laydate=}}</ref><ref>[[Terence Hines|Hines, Terence]]. (2003). ''Pseudoscience and the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. p. 109. {{ISBN|1-57392-979-4}}</ref>
==History== Stories of the [[miracle|miraculous]] abilities of certain individuals to read, write, speak, or understand a foreign language that appear in the Bible and other Christian religious literature went on to inspire similar accounts and stories during the Middle Ages.<ref name="Cooper-Rompato2011">{{citation|author=Christine F. Cooper-Rompato|title=The Gift of Tongues: Women's Xenoglossia in the Later Middle Ages|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pm-YBN-6ZV0C|date=30 April 2011|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=0-271-03615-X|authormask=|format=|origyear=|oclc=|doi=|bibcode=|id=|quote=|laysummary=|laydate=}}</ref> Claims of [[mediumship|mediums]] speaking foreign languages were made by Spiritualists in the 19th century, as well as by [[Pentecostal]]s in the 20th century, but these did not hold up to scientific scrutiny. More recent claims of xenoglossy have come from reincarnation researchers who have alleged that individuals were able to recall a language spoken in a past life.<ref name=Gordon /> Some reports of xenoglossy have surfaced in the popular press, such as Czech speedway rider [[Matěj Kůs]] who in September 2007 supposedly awoke after a crash and was able to converse in perfect English; however press reports of his fluency in English were based entirely on anecdotal stories told by his Czech teammates.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/pages/live/articles/news/news.html?in_article_id=481651&in_page_id=1770 Czech speedway rider knocked out in crash wakes up speaking perfect English | the Daily Mail<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://news.sky.com/skynews/article/0,,91059-1284155,00.html Crash Victim Wakes Up Speaking English]</ref>
==Notable claims==
===Ian Stevenson=== [[Parapsychologist]] and psychiatrist at the University of Virginia [[Ian Stevenson]] claimed there were a handful of cases that suggested evidence of xenoglossy. These included two where a subject under hypnosis could allegedly converse with people speaking the foreign language, instead of merely being able to recite foreign words. [[Sarah Thomason]], a linguist at the University of Michigan, reanalyzed these cases, concluding that "the linguistic evidence is too weak to provide support for the claims of xenoglossy".<ref name="www-personal.umich.edu"/>
*When Stevenson investigated an American housewife known as "T. E" who exhibited the male personality of a Swedish farmer named "Jensen Jacoby" while under hypnosis, he reported that the subject was able to converse in Swedish, albeit not fluently. However, Thomason's reanalysis concluded that "Jensen" could not convincingly be claimed to speak Swedish; writing that though "Jensen" had a total vocabulary of about 100 words, "this is not very impressive when compared with the thousands of words known by any native speaker of any natural language, even taking into account the limited contexts in which Jensen spoke Swedish."<ref name="www-personal.umich.edu"/> Thomason found that "Jensen" gave no complex sentences, mostly giving one or two word answers, and concluded, "[Stevenson's] demonstration that there was no fraud in the case is convincing, but his claim that Jensen had the capacity to speak Swedish is not."<ref name="www-personal.umich.edu"/> Linguist William Samarin drew the same conclusion as Thomason.<ref>Samarin, William J. (1976). ''Review of Ian Stevenson Xenoglossy: A Review and Report of a Case''. ''[[Language (journal)|Language]]'' 52: 270-274.</ref> *Stevenson also investigated another American woman named Dolores Jay who exhibited the personality of a German teenage girl named "Gretchen" while hypnotized. He claimed that the subject was able to converse in German. Thomason's reanalysis, while acknowledging that the evidence against fraud was convincing, concluded that "Gretchen" could not converse fluently in German and that her speech was largely the repetition of German questions with different intonation, or [[utterance]]s of one or two words. Thomason found that the German vocabulary of "Gretchen" was "minute" and her pronunciation was "spotty", adding that Dolores Jay had some previous exposure to German in TV programs and had looked at a German book.<ref name="www-personal.umich.edu"/>
William J. Samarin, a linguist from the [[University of Toronto]] has written that Stevenson had chosen to correspond with linguists in a selective and unprofessional manner. He noted that Stevenson corresponded with one linguist for a period of six years "without raising any discussion about the kinds of thing that linguists would need to know." He also wrote that most of Stevenson's collaborators were "fellow believers" in the paranormal, starting with a preconceived notion.<ref>Samarin, William J. (1976). ''Xenoglossy: A Review and Report of a Case by Ian Stevenson''. ''[[Language (journal)|Language]]''. Vol. 52, No. 1. pp. 270-274.</ref>
Prof. William Frawley in a review for Stevenson's ''Unlearned Language: New Studies in Xenoglossy'' (1984) wrote that he was too uncritically accepting of a paranormal interpretation of the cases. In one case a female subject could only answer yes or no questions in German which Frawley found unimpressive. In another, the female subject could speak [[Bengali language|Bengali]] with a poor pronunciation. Frawley noted that she was raised on the language of [[Marathi language|Marathi]] (related to Bengali), had studied [[Sanskrit]] from which both Marathi and Bengali derive and was living in a town with thousands of [[Bengali people|Bengalis]]. He concluded "Stevenson does not consider enough linguistic evidence in these cases to warrant his metaphysics."<ref>Frawley, William. (1985). ''Unlearned Language: New Studies in Xenoglossy by Ian Stevenson''. ''[[Language (journal)|Language]]''. Vol. 61, No. 3. p. 739.</ref>
The psychologist David Lester also evaluated Stevenson's cases and wrote the subjects made grammatical mistakes, mispronounced words and did not show a wide vocabulary of words in foreign language, thus they cannot be considered evidence for xenoglossy.<ref>Lester, David. (2005). ''Is There Life After Death? An Examination of the Empirical Evidence''. McFarland. pp. 123-131. {{ISBN|978-0786421169}}</ref>
===Alfred Hulme===
In the early 20th century Alfred Hulme, a self-proclaimed [[Egyptologist]], investigated a young girl named Ivy Carter Beaumont also known as "Rosemary" from [[Blackpool]], [[England]] who claimed to be under the influence of the personality of a Babylonian princess. Hulme was convinced she spoke in an [[Egyptian language|ancient Egyptian]] dialect. However, according to linguist [[Karen Stollznow]] "Several scholars examined the data independently and concluded that Hulme's analyses were grossly inaccurate. Hulme had confused Middle Egyptian and Late Egyptian [...] they also found evidence that he had falsified many results."<ref>[[Karen Stollznow|Stollznow, Karen]]. (2014). ''Language Myths, Mysteries and Magic''. Palgrave Macmillan. pp. 86-86. {{ISBN|978-1-137-40484-8}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Foreign accent syndrome]] *[[Glossolalia]] *[[Telepathy]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *Cooper-Rompato, Christine F. (2010). ''The Gift of Tongues: Women's Xenoglossia in the Later Middle Ages''. Pennsylvania State University Press. {{ISBN|0-271-03615-X}} *Samarin, William J. (1976). ''Review of Ian Stevenson Xenoglossy: A Review and Report of a Case''. Language 52: 270-274. *Stevenson, Ian. (1966). ''[[Twenty Cases Suggestive of Reincarnation]]''. (Second revised and enlarged edition 1974). University of Virginia Press. {{ISBN|0-8139-0872-8}} *Stevenson, Ian. (1974). ''Xenoglossy: A Review and Report of a Case''. Charlotte: University Press of Virginia. *Stevenson, Ian. (1984). ''Unlearned Language: New Studies in Xenoglossy''. University of Virginia Press. {{ISBN|0-8139-0994-5}} *Stevenson, Ian. (2001). ''Children Who Remember Previous Lives: A Quest of Reincarnation''. McFarland & Company. {{ISBN|0-7864-0913-4}} *[[Karen Stollznow|Stollznow, Karen]]. (2014). ''Language Myths, Mysteries and Magic''. Palgrave Macmillan. {{ISBN|978-1-137-40484-8}} *[[Sarah Thomason|Thomason, Sarah G.]] (1984). ''Do you Remember Your Previous Life's Language in Your Present Incarnation?''. American Speech 59: 340-350. *[[Sarah Thomason|Thomason, Sarah G.]] (1987). ''Past Tongues Remembered?''. The Skeptical Inquirer 11: 367-75. *[[Sarah Thomason|Thomason, Sarah G.]] [http://www-personal.umich.edu/~thomason/papers/xenogl.pdf "Xenoglossy"]. In [[Gordon Stein]]. (1996). ''The Encyclopedia of the Paranormal''. Prometheus Books. {{ISBN|1-57392-021-5}}

{{Infobox Organization |name = Yale World Fellows |image = Yale World Fellows.png |image_border = |size =280px |formation = 2002 |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |headquarters = [[Betts House (Yale University)|Betts House]] |location = [[New Haven, Connecticut|New Haven]], [[Connecticut]] |region_served = Worldwide |parent_organization = [[Yale University]] |leader_title = Director |leader_name = [[Emma Sky]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.yale.edu/2015/01/08/international-activist-emma-sky-direct-world-fellows-program |title=International activist Emma Sky to direct World Fellows Program |date=8 January 2015 |website= |publisher=Yale University }}</ref> |website = [http://worldfellows.yale.edu worldfellows.yale.edu] }}
'''Yale World Fellows''' is an international fellowship program at [[Yale University]] for mid-career emerging leaders who have distinguished themselves in their profession, discipline, or geographic region. Each year, between fifteen and twenty participants, known as World Fellows, reside at Yale for the fall academic term.
World Fellows are selected from a wide range of fields and disciplines including government, business, nongovernmental organizations, religion, military, media, and the arts.<ref>{{cite news | title =Yale World Fellows Program |author=U.S. Embassy, Seoul, Korea |publisher =U.S. Department of State |url = http://seoul.usembassy.gov/p_an_111708.html | year =2008 |accessdate =19 November 2013 }}</ref> While at Yale, World Fellows participate in a global affairs seminar, leadership workshops, and Yale courses.
The program's main facilities are located in [[Betts House (Yale University)|Betts House]], a university-owned mansion in the [[Prospect Hill Historic District (New Haven, Connecticut)|Prospect Hill Historic District]] of [[New Haven, Connecticut]].
==Origin== In November 2000, University President [[Rick Levin]] announced several internationalization initiatives, including the World Fellows program, in conjunction with the university's tercentenary.<ref>{{cite news |last=Folk |first=Elyssa |title=Yale To Go Global in Its Fourth Century |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=20 April 2001 |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2001/04/20/yale-to-go-global-in-its-fourth-century/ |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> Journalist and [[White House]] aide [[Brooke Shearer]] was appointed its founding director, and [[Dan Esty]] its first program director.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.yale.edu/opa/arc-ybc/v29.n11/story1.html |accessdate=25 April 2014 |title=Strobe Talbott to head Center for Study of Globalization |magazine=Yale Bulletin & Calendar |volume=29 |number=11 |date=17 November 2011 |publisher=Yale Office of Public Affairs & Communications}}</ref> The program moved into Betts House, restored in 2001 to house new international initiatives.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.yale.edu/opa/arc-ybc/v30.n7/story1.html |accessdate=24 April 2014 |title=Davies Mansion To Be Renovated, Renamed |journal=Yale Bulletin & Calendar |publisher=Yale Office of Public Affairs & Communications |volume=30 |number=7 |date=19 October 2011}}</ref> The first class of fellows was admitted in 2002.<ref name="Pearce">{{cite news |last=Pearce |first=Sarah |title=First batch of World Fellows selected |newspaper=Yale Daily News |date=24 April 2002 |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2002/04/24/first-batch-of-world-fellows-selected/ |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=World Class |last=Shufro |first=Kathy |magazine=[[Yale Alumni Magazine]] |url=http://archives.yalealumnimagazine.com/issues/2005_05/fellows.html |date=May–June 2005 |accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
Since the program's establishment, 257 World Fellows have been selected for the program, representing 83 countries.<ref>{{cite news |last=Ramiah |first=Uma | title=Sixteen global leaders named 2014 Yale World Fellows |website=Yale News |publisher=Yale Office of Public Affairs & Communications |url=http://news.yale.edu/2014/04/07/sixteen-global-leaders-named-2014-yale-world-fellows |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
==Program== [[File:Betts House horizontal Highsmith.jpg|thumb|right|[[Betts House (Yale University)|Betts House]], the program's administrative building]] The center of the Yale World Fellows Program is a 15-week global affairs [[seminar]] taught by distinguished Yale faculty. Each class of World Fellows is exposed to both classical philosophical texts and current academic research.<ref name="ARMACAD">{{cite news |title=Yale World Fellows Program 2014| author=Armenian Association for Academic Partnership and Support (ARMACAD) |publisher=ARMACAD |url=http://armacad.blogspot.com/2013/08/2014-yale-world-fellows-program-is-now.html |date=3 December 2012 |accessdate=19 November 2013}}</ref>
Sessions are facilitated by [[Yale School of Management]] faculty in entrepreneurship and innovation. They also receive individualized coaching in public speaking.<ref name="Zelizer">{{cite web |title=Call for Applications: Yale World Fellows Program, Yale University |last=Zelizer |first=Craig |publisher=Alliance for Peacebuilding |url=http://www.allianceforpeacebuilding.org/2013/10/call-for-applications-yale-world-fellows-program-yale-university/ |date=28 October 2013 |accessdate=19 November 2013}}</ref>
In an off-the-record conversation series, Fellows have the opportunity to ask questions of global practitioners(?). The program has hosted leaders like [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|United Nations Secretary-General]] [[Kofi Annan]], former heads of state [[Ernesto Zedillo]] and [[Tony Blair]], [[List of Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States|U.S. Supreme Court Justices]] [[Stephen Breyer]] and [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]], and writers [[David Brooks (journalist)|David Brooks]] and [[Elizabeth Alexander (poet)|Elizabeth Alexander]].<ref name="Zelizer" />
Fellows can audit almost any course offered at Yale University with the opportunity to develop individual or collaborative research projects. They also spend time with Yale faculty and students, giving lectures and engaging in informal dialogue.<ref name="ARMACAD" /> While most program activities take place on campus in New Haven, the program sponsors trips to New York City and Washington, DC.<ref>{{cite news | title =Yale World Fellows Program 2014 |last=Omolayo |first=Louis | publisher=International Youth Council |url=http://internationalyouthcouncil.com/forum/topics/yale-world-fellows-program |date =30 October 2013 | accessdate =19 November 2013 }}</ref>
==Activities== The program sponsors a variety of events every year, including global conferences, multimedia exhibitions, and panel discussions on current events. World Fellows often initiate their own collaborative projects while at Yale, such as the Seven Billionth Person Project, an international multimedia effort that invites people to share through writings and art what they would say to the world's seven billionth baby, expected to be born sometime in 2011. In the same year, the Yale World Fellows hosted Yale University's first [[TED (conference)|TEDx]] event, "TEDx Yale World Fellows". The Return to Yale Forum is held every other year, and brings together current and former World Fellows to meet and engage in debates about contemporary issues. The most recent Forum was held in October 2013 and included discussions on social entrepreneurship, corporate thinking, activism, art and culture and peace.<ref>{{cite news | title =World Fellows Forum encourages rethinking of ideas |last=Salam |first=Akash |newspaper =[[Yale Daily News]] |url=http://yaledailynews.com/blog/2013/10/15/world-fellows-forum-encourages-rethinking-of-ideas/ |date=15 October 2013 |accessdate=18 November 2013}}</ref>
The World Fellows Program also sponsors an annual Global Leadership Series conference. At these conferences held in cities internationally, World Fellows alumni, leaders in the region, prospective World Fellows nominees, and others debate selected global topics. Past conferences have addressed issues such as the United Nations Global Compact's contribution for addressing corporate social responsibility.<ref>{{cite news | title =Yale Convenes Conference on Occasion of Global Compact's 10th Anniversary| author=Deniz Ozturk |publisher=[[United Nations Development Programme]] |url=http://www.unglobalcompact.org/news/35-05-28-2010 |date=28 May 2010 |accessdate =24 March 2011}}</ref>
==Selection== Candidates for the program must be: :*a citizen of a country other than the United States; :*fluent in English; :*in their early mid-career, roughly 5–20 years into their professional lives.
Approximately 15–20 World Fellows are selected for the program each year. World Fellows are selected for their work accomplishments and indications of future contributions and leadership. They are required to reside full-time at Yale and participate in university life. In 2013, approximately 2,500 candidates applied for the program.<ref>{{cite web |last=Powell |first=Leslie |title=Yale selects its 2013 World Fellows |url=http://news.yale.edu/2013/04/02/yale-selects-its-2013-world-fellows |date=2 April 2013 |website=Yale News |publisher=Yale Office of Public Affairs and Communications |accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref>
Candidates can be nominated by anyone, or can apply of their own initiative. Regional panels review semifinalist candidates, and a final selection committee aims to assemble a class of fellows that is diverse, geographically balanced, and representative of a wide range of professions, talents, and perspectives.<ref>{{cite news | title=Yale World Fellows Program for Mid-Career Leaders |author=mladi info |publisher =mladi info |url=http://www.mladiinfo.eu/blog/2013/11/13/yale-world-fellows-program-for-mid-career-leaders/ |date=13 November 2013 |accessdate =19 November 2013}}</ref>
==Notable fellows== *[[Alexey Navalny]], a Moscow-based lawyer and political opposition leader, named one of [[Time Magazine]]'s 2012 100 Most Influential People<ref>{{cite journal |last=Kasparov |first=Garry |author-link=Garry Kasparov |title =The 100 Most Influential People in the World |magazine=[[Time Magazine]] |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2111975_2111976_2112167,00.html |date =18 April 2012 | accessdate=23 April 2014}}</ref> *[[Tim Jarvis]], Australian environmental scientist<ref>{{cite news |title=Australian adventurer Tim Jarvis to lead re-creation of Antarctic voyage | newspaper=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=20 March 2012 |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/australian-adventurer-tim-jarvis-to-lead-re-creation-of-shackleton-antarctic-voyage/story-e6frg6so-1226304947428 |accessdate=26 April 2014}}</ref> *[[María Corina Machado]], Venezuelan Congresswoman and opposition leader<ref>{{cite news |title=Rivals seek new inroads against Venezuela's Chavez |author= |publisher=Associated Press | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i4GbPAkBn8h0Kyv3OGIp0E1jHMFA?docId=e54849fa742e48f1ae415d23ab30c470 |date=26 March 2011 |accessdate=31 March 2011}}</ref> *[[Gidon Bromberg]], Israeli environmental activist, named one of ''Time's'' "Environmental Heroes of the Year" in 2008<ref>{{cite journal |title=Heroes of the Environment 2008| last=Lee Butters |first= Andrew |magazine =[[Time Magazine]] |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1841778_1841781_1841807,00.html |date =24 September 2008 | accessdate =23 April 2014}}</ref> *[[Aboubakr Jamaï]], Moroccan journalist, co-founder of ''Le Journal Hebdomadaire''<ref>{{cite news |last=Kramer |first=Jane |author-link=Jane Kramer |title=The Crusader |publisher=[[The New Yorker]] |url=http://www.newyorker.com/archive/2006/10/16/061016fa_fact_kramer | date=16 October 2006 |accessdate =23 April 2014}}</ref> *[[Ma Jun]], environmental activist, winner of the 2012 Goldman Environmental Prize<ref>{{cite news |title=Advocate helps track polluters on supply chain |last=Gies |first=Erica |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/04/23/business/global/advocate-helps-track-polluters-on-supply-chain.html |date =22 April 2012 |accessdate=23 April 2013 }}</ref> *[[Norbert Mao]], [[Ugandan general election, 2011|2011 presidential candidate]] for the [[Democratic Party (Uganda)|Democratic Party of Uganda]]<ref>{{cite web | title=Norbert Mao, Uganda Democratic Party Presidential Candidate 2011| publisher='norbertmao.org'| date= | url=http://www.norbertmao.org |accessdate =31 March 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Kwesiga |first=Pascal |title=Mao getting DP set for 2016 elections |newspaper=Sunday Vision |url=http://www.sundayvision.co.ug/detail.php?mainNewsCategoryId=7&newsCategoryId=128&newsId=747621 |date=26 February 2011 |accessdate = }}</ref> *[[Mohamed Elfayoumy]], Egyptian diplomat and Consul of Egypt in Damascus from 2010-2012.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://almogaz.com/news/politics/2013/03/04/755029 |accessdate=24 April 2014 |title=Foreign Minister Appoints Fayoumy to Communicate with the Syrian Opposition|language=Arabic}}</ref> *[[Rui Chenggang]], Chinese news anchor<ref>{{cite news |title=Celebrity CCTV Anchor Rui Chenggang Detained Amid Corruption Crackdown |date=July 2014 |publisher=China Digital Times |url=http://chinadigitaltimes.net/2014/07/celebrity-cctv-anchor-rui-chenggang-detained-amid-corruption-crackdown/ |accessdate=15 July 2014}}</ref> *[[Martín Lousteau]], National Deputy and Ex-Minister of Economy of Argentina. Actual Embassador of Argentina in United States. *[[Belabbes Benkredda]], Algerian-German social innovator, 2013 NDI Democracy Award recipient <ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.exeter.ac.uk/alumnisupporters/news/alumni/title_346542_en.html |accessdate=21 October 2016 |title=International democracy award for graduate }}</ref> *[[Marvin Rees]], Mayor of [[Bristol]], United Kingdom.
